	Andrea	Allan	Allan, Andrea M.		Professor		Research in this laboratory focuses on the neurochemical mechanisms of learning and memory, substance abuse and neurotoxic effects of prenatal exposures (e.g., drugs, toxins). Within the area of drug abuse we are interested in how drug abuse is set up and the neural pathways associated with reward and impulse control. We are interested in evaluating the role that the HPA axis plays in many of these phenomenon. Clinically our research interest is in the areas of stress responding, depression, Post traumatic stress disorder, drug abuse, ADHD and autism. Our recent work investigates the role of developmental insults on epigenetic machinery and how these changes relate to behavior and biochemistry in the adult animal Techniques employed are basic and behavioral pharmacology, biochemistry, receptor measurements, second messenger singling pathways, enzymatic measurements, measurements of neurogenesis and inflammatory mediators, immunological techniques, molecular and Mendelian genetics.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n444									AAllan@Salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Sarah	Allen	Allen, Sarah	87131	Professor		Dr. Sarah Allen is a Professor of Medicine. &#160;She is the Program Director for the Infectious Diseases Fellowship and the director of the Outpatient Parenteral Antibiotic Treatment (OPAT) Clinic. &#160;<br />Dr. Allen received her Bachelor's and Master's from Stanford University. She was an early graduate of Stanford's Program in Human Biology, founded by Dr. Jane Goodall and the subsequent director of the FDA and Stanford president, Dr. Donald Kennedy. Dr. Allen received her MD from the University of Louisville School of Medicine. She completed her residency in Internal Medicine and fellowship in Infectious Diseases at the University of New Mexico. Following her fellowship training, Dr. Allen joined the UNM Infectious Diseases faculty for 14 years. &#160;During this time Dr. Allen was Visting Professor at Moi University in Eldoret, Kenya. &#160;She also travelled and worked in Cote D'Ivoire. A memoir of Dr. Allen's African experiences is captured in her book, "Africa Letters." In 2005, Dr. Allen joined the faculty of Baylor College of Medicine for 7 years where she was co-director of the Adult Cystic Fibrosis Clinic and managed the inpatient CF service bridging patients with end-stage CF patients to lung transplant. Dr. Allen returned to UNM in 2012 to become the ID Fellowship Program Director. Albuquerque	Wadih	Arap	Arap, Wadih	87131-0001	Tenured Professor		As a physican-scientist, my laboratory-based research focuses on the rapid translation of discoveries into clinical applications.&nbsp; I am the Hansen Surface Professor of Medicine, Chief of Hem/Onc and Deputy Director of the University of New Mexico Cancer Center.&nbsp;&nbsp; As a physician-scientist, in addition to my administrative leadership responsibilities, I currently treat cancer patients and co-direct the Arap/Pasqualini Laboratory at the UNMCC.&nbsp; As a matter of record, Dr. Pasqualini and I have a long-standing collaboration and have led a joint laboratory (please note that we are husband and wife) since October 1999.&nbsp; We have published over 150 original peer-reviewed research manuscripts and, with very few exceptions, such publications are a team science effort.&nbsp; Our research group currently includes PhD or MD/PhD students, postdoctoral fellows, faculty (assistant and associate professors), research technicians, and administrative staff members.&nbsp; Our central working hypothesis is that differential protein expression in the human vascular endothelium associated with normal or diseased tissues offers the potential for developing novel diagnostic, imaging, and therapeutic strategies.&nbsp; In essence, our research program uses combinatorial library selection (peptide- and antibody-based) to discover, validate, and exploit the vascular biochemical diversity of endothelial cell surfaces towards a new vascular-targeted pharmacology.&nbsp; Such targeting technologies may lead to the developemtn of ligand-directed agents for application int he treatment of cancer patients.&nbsp; Translational applications, such as first-in-man clinical trials will determine the value of this strategy.&nbsp; Indeed, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) granted "save-to-proceed" status for our first vascular-targeted IND in 2009 and a first-in-human study has already been completed, successfully meeting its biological end points.&nbsp; A second Phase I study is now active.&nbsp; Two other drugs are in pre-IND stage and several others in pre-clinical laboratory phase.&nbsp; Long-term, the broader vision of our research is a large-scale mapping of the receptors in human vasculature towards a new ligand-directed pharmacology.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2916	Cancer Therapeutics: Technology, Discovery and Targeted Delivery	New Mexico	UNM Cancer Center, 1 University of New Mexico, MSC07 4025		United States of America				warap@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Sally	Bachefor	Bachefor, Sally				<p class="MsoNormal">Dr. Sally Bachofer is Board Certified in Family Medicine and has practiced in community and academic settings. Her educational focus has been integrating population/community health into the medical school and residency curricula. An important aspect of this educational effort has been to create teaching opportunities and curricula that instill an appreciation for the incorporation of the social determinants of health into the daily practice of medicine.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal">She is a founding faculty member of the Family Medical Home model for the FOCUS Early Intervention Program. This program works with families of children under the age of three years who are struggling with adverse social situations such as chronic mental illness, substance use, violence, poverty and incarceration. &nbsp;The clinical component is integrated into the continuity clinical experience for FM residents which provides the opportunity to train future family physicians in an interdisciplinary approach to primary care and incorporate Medication Assisted Treatment of Substance Use Disorders. &nbsp;In her residency faculty role, she leads the Population Health &amp; Scholarship curriculum and shares her passion for incorporating advocacy and policy into the role of family physicians.&nbsp;</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n86578									sbachofer@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Edward	Bedrick	Bedrick, Edward	87131	<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Biostatistics</p>  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Professor</p>  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Associate Chief, Division</p>  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Director for Biostatistics Core in the CTSA and the UNM Cancer Center</p>				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7307	I am currently developing biostatistical methods in three distinct areas. One project involves novel methods for meta-analysis and tests of equivalence with time-to-event data. This project is motivated by collaborations with clinicians at UNM and Dialysis Clinics Incorporated. A second project involves the development of statistical methods for inferring animal diet from stable isotope data. This is joint work with E. Erhardt of UNM. A third project examines the impact of summarizing data prior to performing statistical inference, which is common with high-dimensional data where for example, an estimated principal component may be used as the response in a regression model or in ANOVA. In addition to my methodological research, I am involved in collaborative projects with faculty members of the Department of Internal Medicine and at the UNM Cancer Center. Albuquerque	Marianne	Berwick	Berwick, Marianne	87131	Distinguished Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7828	<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Dr. Berwick is currently working on several areas of melanoma etiology and progression.&nbsp; She and her colleagues are bringing together a new consortium, InterMEL, that consists of 18 sites in 4 countries with more than 16,000 melanoma patients with annotation, germline DNA and more than 6,000 tumors.&nbsp; This consortium will provide a platform for new grant ideas that focus on survival with melanoma, in particular genetic factors associated with survival.&nbsp; She is also continuing the GEM (Genes, Environment and Melanoma) study, where we have DNA and full annotation for 3,580 individuals with melanoma and 1,500 tumors.&nbsp; In this study, the focus continues on risk and survival.&nbsp; Other work is investigating risk factors for nevus formation, the strongest risk factor for melanoma development.&nbsp; She is also working with two large cohort studies, one in Colorado and one in Framingham, Massachusetts, to follow young individuals over time to catalog the development of nevi.&nbsp; In addition, she is also conducting some skin cancer prevention work with Dave Buller in Colorado by developing a smart phone app for sun protection.&nbsp; She was recently awarded the highest faculty rank at the University of New Mexico, that of Distinguished Professor.</p>	New Mexico	Division of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Preventive Medicine, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				MBerwick@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Cristian	Bologa	Bologa, Cristian G.	87131	Research Professor		<p class="MsoNormal">Dr. Bologa has been involved during the last 10 years in the data management, workflow processing, and the decision making for the discovery of new bioactive compounds in the Division of Biocomputing and Division of Translational Informatics at UNM. He has a broad background and more than 15 years experience in protein and small molecule modeling, screening informatics, chemoinformatics, and SAR for molecular discovery. He had significant contributions in developing and using new methods and tools for discovery of novel small bioactive molecules for integrins (LFA-1 and VLA-4), formyl peptide receptors (FPR-1 and FPRL1), for granularity induction in prostate cancer cell lines (LNCaP and PC3), for the anti-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family protein Bcl-B, and a very potent and selective agonist (G&#8209;1) for a membrane estrogen receptor (GPR30). 	Blake	Boursaw	Boursaw, Blake		Instructor		Blake Boursaw was born and raised in rural Michigan and was a devoted lover of mathematics from the very start. He pursued graduate study in "pure" mathematics at the University of Minnesota and was full time faculty in mathematics at Augsburg College, a small liberal arts college in Minneapolis, before moving to New Mexico in 2006. Since moving to Albuquerque, he has picked up mountain trail running as a hobby and has completed the La Luz Trail Run twice and finish dead last and extremely happily at the Run the Caldera Marathon in June of 2012. Blake began working at UNM for the RWJF Center for Health Policy in 2007, and, while there, picked up a habit of longboarding in to campus. During his time at the Center, he served as a statistical mentor with select doctoral students of color in the social sciences and expanded his research interests from a purely academic focus on geometric group theory to encompass the fascinating quantitative phenomena that arise at the intersection of statistical methodology and lived experience. He collaborates widely with researchers in the social sciences, nursing, and public health.<br /><br /><br />		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n4506									bboursaw@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Steven	Bradfute	Bradfute, Steven B		Assistant Professor		<p class="MsoNormal">Steven B. Bradfute, Ph.D., is an Assistant Professor in the UNM Center for Global Health and Department of Internal Medicine.&nbsp; Dr. Bradfute received his Ph.D. in Immunology from Baylor College of Medicine (2005) and did a postdoctoral fellowship at the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases (USAMRIID), where he studied immune responses to hemorrhagic fever viruses, including the filoviruses (ebolaviruses, marburgviruses, and cuevaviruses). &nbsp;Filoviruses can cause severe disease in humans, and there have been increases in filovirus prevalence and geographical spread in recent years.&nbsp; As there are few treatments or vaccines available for many of these viruses, Dr. Bradfute is&#8203;&nbsp;interested in basic immunology and vaccine development for these and other emerging pathogens.&nbsp; Current projects in the lab include development and testing of vaccines and determination of the mechanisms of immunity for filoviruses and other emerging pathogens, including Zika viruses.&nbsp; He has existing collaborations with researchers at USAMRIID, the Los Alamos National Laboratory, and the National Institutes of Health.&nbsp;</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1069296486	<p class="MsoNormal">My work has focused on how emerging viral pathogens bypass immune responses, and development of vaccines for these pathogens. &nbsp;Currently, we are working on improving existing Ebola and Marburg virus vaccines by modifying the viral glycoproteins to induce more effective immune responses. &nbsp;Other projects in the lab include development and testing of vaccines against Zika viruses, and and determination of the mechanisms of immunity of efficacious viral vaccines. &nbsp;</p>								sbradfute@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Distance Services also offers support to faculty and students affiliated with the University of New Mexico who are involved in community health-related projects. The <a href="nativeservices/index.html" title="Native Services">Native American Health Information Services (NAHIS)</a>, offers health resources and training to healthcare providers serving Native Americans, the Native American community at the University of New Mexico, and community members of the 22 Native nations in New Mexico.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n6529									PBradley@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Denis	Bragin	Bragin, Denis		Assistant Professor		<p>Bragin received his MSc in biochemistry from Rostov State University (Russia) in 1999. He completed his post-graduate work at the Kogan&rsquo;s Research Institute for Neurocybernetics, where he studied the effects of photodynamic treatment on neurons and defended his PhD in biophysics in Voronezh State University/Russian Academy of Sciences in 2004. He joined UNM&rsquo;s Department of Neurosurgery in 2005 as a postdoctoral fellow researching epilepsy, stroke and brain trauma. In 2011 he was promoted as an assistant professor at the Department of Neurosurgery.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Bragin&prime;s research focuses on the circulation and metabolism of the brain after the stroke and traumatic brain injury. His current research interests include:</p>  <ul>  <li>The role of cerebral microvascular shunting in the development of hyperemia, brain edema, tissue ischemia and blood-brain barrier degradation during intracranial hypertension after severe cerebral insults.</li>  <li>The potential of hemodynamics modulation with drag-reducing molecules for treating acute and chronic cerebral microvascular disorders and ischemia including stroke, traumatic injury and neurodegenerative diseases.</li>  <li>Non-invasive transcranial direct current and pulsed electromagnetic field brain stimulations for recovery after acute brain injuries.</li>  </ul>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n609									DBragin@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Fink, PhD		Assistant Professor<br /><br /><br />		<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>   <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>    <o:RelyOnVML/>    <o:AllowPNG/>   </o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  </xml><![endif]-->  <p class="MsoTitle" style="text-align: left;">I am interested in a contextual approach to studying how severe marital and family dysfunction contribute to the development of severe public health problems such as alcohol associated intimate partner violence, substance abuse, and severe behavioral problems in adolescents. Of particular interest are using neuropsychophysiological approaches to understand the association between alcohol use and the increase in severity and frequency of intimate partner violence in order to develop novel interventions for this problem.&nbsp; Similarly, I am interested in biopotential predictors, such as event related potentials, of the discontinuation of substance abuse treatments and the return to substance use after treatment.&nbsp; The goal of this work is also to develop novel interventions that improve substance abuse treatment outcomes.</p>  <!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> mso 10]>  <style>   /* Style Definitions */   table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:10.0pt;   font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;}  </style>  <![endif]-->		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n14868	<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>   <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>    <o:RelyOnVML/>    <o:AllowPNG/>   </o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  </xml><![endif]-->  <p class="MsoTitle" style="text-align: left;">I am interested in a contextual approach to studying how severe marital and family dysfunction contribute to the development of severe public health problems such as alcohol associated intimate partner violence, substance abuse, and severe behavioral problems in adolescents. Of particular interest are using neuropsychophysiological approaches to understand the association between alcohol use and the increase in severity and frequency of intimate partner violence in order to develop novel interventions for this problem.&nbsp; Similarly, I am interested in biopotential predictors, such as event related potentials, of the discontinuation of substance abuse treatments and the return to substance use after treatment.&nbsp; The goal of this work is also to develop novel interventions that improve substance abuse treatment outcomes.</p>  <!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> 	Jonathan	Brigman	Brigman, Jonathan				The focus of our research is to further our understanding of the maladaptive behavioral changes that accompany alcohol abuse , drug addiction and numerous neuropsychiatric disorders.&nbsp; Current theories have proposed that early or repeated alcohol exposure can lead to progressive loss of cortically-mediated executive control. As top-top down control is lost, habitual alcohol or drug seeking comes to dominate the behavioral repertoire leading to decreased quality of life.&nbsp; If this maladaptive shift in behavior could be prevented or reversed, it would provide an important therapeutic tool for combating addiction. Our research focuses on developing models that allow us to investigate the role of both genetic factors and molecular mechanisms in mediating executive control behaviors, both before and after drug and alcohol exposure.&nbsp; One potential mechanism of interest due to its established role in the neuro-plasticity underlying learning and memory is the glutamatergic N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR).&nbsp; We are currently exploring how NMDAR subunit composition and receptor expression is altered by alcohol exposure.&nbsp; Another major focus of the lab is understanding the optimal organization of neuronal firing in corticostriatal circuits in vivo, and how alterations in NMDAR may disrupt these patterns, leading to loss of executive control and poorer functional outcome.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1481									JBrigman@Salud.UNM.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Holly	Buchanan	Buchanan, Holly	87131-0001	Professor		<strong>HSLIC&nbsp;Responsibilities</strong>  <ul>  <li>Strategic visioning and the HSLIC brand image</li>  <li>Fund development; resource allocation for success and funding strategies</li>  <li>Human resources development</li>  <li>Facilities planning</li>  <li>Measures of quality, effectiveness, and outcome</li>  <li>Professional relationships and partnership development</li>  </ul>  <strong>Contact me for assistance with:</strong>  <ul>  <li>Strategic planning for your component or department dealing with library services, technology support, informatics, or education development</li>  <li>Grants requiring HSLIC support of investigators</li>  <li>Changing models of scholarly communication</li>  <li>New trends and technology</li>  </ul>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7263		New Mexico	UNM Health Sciences Library and Informatics Center, MSC 09 5100, 1 University of New Mexico	informatics	United States of America				hbuchanan@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Amy	Buesing	Buesing, Amy						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n54090										thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Brian	Bunnett	Bunnett, Brian		Director, Library and Education Services				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n6751				Library Administration					BBunnettsalud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Tione	Buranda	Buranda, Tione						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2055203233	<ul>  <li>Plasma membrane organization, signaling and cell adhesion.</li>  <li>Spatiotemporal aspects of signaling and internalization.</li>  <li>Virus-host cell interactions (attachment and entry, effects on signal transduction, identification of new molecular targets relevant to viral pathogenesis: new approaches to identify cellular changes relevant to pathogenic mechanisms).</li>  </ul>  <p><strong>Overview.</strong> I am formally trained in experimental physical chemistry specializing in laser spectroscopy and the measurement of fast electron and energy transfer processes in molecular complexes. My expertise in cell biology was gained through a 5 year NIAID-funded Mentored Quantitative Research Development Award (K25) entitled &ldquo;Membrane Organization in Cell Signaling and Adhesion&rdquo;. My long-term scientific interests are to understand mechanisms that govern the responses of cells to a wide range of environmental stimuli. These interests have been shaped through interactions with mentors and colleagues in the areas of cell signaling adhesion, trafficking, virology and drug discovery. The experimental approaches are inherently interdisciplinary and collaborative. We use a variety of novel nanotechnologies and quantitative fluorescence measurement capabilities, which include real time quantitative nanoscopic FRET measurements by flow cytometry and live cell microscopy imaging. In collaboration with the NIH Roadmap New Mexico Center for Molecular Discovery, we are engaged in efforts to develop flow cytometry based high throughput screening (HTS) assays for small molecule inhibitors of viral entry. Unified themes are being pursued under the areas described below.</p>  <p><strong>Membrane Organization.</strong> We are interested in establishing methods and concepts of measuring membrane reorganization dynamics on the same timescale as signaling events. This requires a full understanding of the spatial and temporal complexity of cell membranes, which include concepts of signaling microdomains, membrane rafts and lipid shells. We are currently focused on cell signaling events that are induced by virus-host cell interactions and ligands for receptors such as integrins and GPCRs.</p>  <p><strong>Membrane rafts, cell signaling, adhesion and viral-host cell interactions.</strong> Our mechanistic studies of viral-host cell interactions, attempt to address the central hypothesis that the bidirectional signaling of Rho family GTPases (Rac1, Cdc42, and RhoA) and integrins is required for selection of the correct entry and endocytic pathway to viral replication. Viruses are believed to enter and exit cells through rafts, taking advantage of signaling elements that are bundled in raft domains. Fluorescently labeled viruses are excellent probes for analyzing virus-host cell interactions by flow cytometry and live microscopy imaging. In collaboration with the Hjelle lab, our current work focuses on the use of UV-inactivated hantavirus particles to examine virus host cell interactions of BSL-3 viruses, using the broad array of research tools available in a BSL-2 laboratory. Our methods and concepts are applicable to multiple classes of enveloped viruses.</p>  <p><strong>Development of HTS Platform for small molecule inhibitors of viral-host cell interactions.</strong> We have established a robust high throughput assay for the discovery of small molecule inhibitors of specific binding interactions between enveloped viruses and cognate cell entry receptors using HTS flow cytometry. We use TEM measurements, absorption and fluorescence spectroscopies to characteize virus particles in terms of size and measurement of discretely defined number of fluorophores/particle. Quantification of virus particles assures batch-to-batch consistency over time.</p>								TBuranda@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Scott	Burchiel	Burchiel, Scott		Professor		<p>Burchiel received a BS in biochemistry from the University of California, Davis, in 1973 and a PhD in pharmacology from the University of California, San Francisco, in 1977. He was a postdoctoral fellow at UNM School of Medicine&rsquo;s Immunology Laboratory before joining the College of Pharmacy.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Burchiel is an expert in immunotoxicology and environmental carcinogenesis. He has written more than 125 scientific manuscripts and has been continually funded by the NIH for more than 25 years. He is an active NIH reviewer and is an Editor in Chief of Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology. His research focuses on the effects of environmental agents on the immune system of humans and animal models, gene-environment interactions and epigenetics of immune suppression. Burchiel&rsquo;s laboratory is known for its use of flow cytometry to study immune cell phenotyping and function, as well as signaling and cell injury pathways. Current studies focus on environmental public health issues in populations exposed to arsenic.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2458									SBurchiel@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Mark	Burge	Burge, Mark R	87131	Professor of Medicine, Endocrinology and Metabolism		<p class="datafield11pt" style="text-indent: 0.25in; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Mark R. Burge, MD, is an established clinical and translational investigator in diabetes at the University of New Mexico HSC. &#160;His R01-funded studies have thus far focused on the physiology and pathophysiology of hypoglycemia in patients with type 2 diabetes and on improving treatments for individuals with type 1 and type 2 diabetes.&#160; He has also participated as a co-investigator at the New Mexico site in landmark diabetes-related clinical trials, including the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and the Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP).&#160; Dr. Burge&#8217;s current research is aimed at establishing a comprehensive cohort of prediabetes subjects as a repository for future research studies.&#160; This work is supported by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and focuses on New Mexico populations that suffer disproportionately from health disparity.</p>  <p class="datafield11pt" style="line-height: normal; text-indent: 0.25in; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Dr. Burge served as the longstanding Program Director of the UNM General Clinical Research Center (GCRC) and is currently the Deputy Director of UNM&#8217;s new Clinical and Translational Science Center (CTSC). Before that, he served as the Research Subject Advocate for the UNM GCRC, and he is well familiar with Data Safety and Monitoring requirements and the functions of a DSMB in the proposed study.&#160; He has also successfully applied for an IND in the past.&#160;&#160;</p>  <p class="datafield11pt" style="line-height: normal; text-indent: 0.25in; margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Dr. Burge is a recent past-President of the American Federation for Medical Research (AFMR) and current President of the Western Society for Clinical Investigation (WSCI).&#160;&#160;</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n95	My research specializes in novel treatments for type 1 and type 2 diabetes, as well as investigations into the pathophysiology of acute and chronic complications of those diseases,&#160;with a special interest in hypoglycemia in type 2 diabetes.&#160;	New Mexico	Division of Endocrinology and Metabolism, DoIM MSC 10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico	Diabetes;Hypoglycemia;Therapeutics;Physiology;Insulin	United States of America				MBurge@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Matthew	Campen	Campen, Matthew		Regents' Professor		<strong>Education</strong><br /><br />Campen received a BS in biochemistry from Virginia Tech in 1994 and a Master of Science in Public Health concentrating on environmental health from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, in 1997. He received his PhD, in environmental health from UNC Chapel Hill in 2000 followed by a postdoctoral fellowship at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. Prior to his current appointment, he worked as an independent scientist at the Lovelace Respiratory Research Institute in Albuquerque.  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Campen is an expert in the cardiopulmonary health effects of air pollution, such as ozone, combustion emissions and nanomaterials. He is also broadly interested in the crosstalk of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems in health and disease, conducting basic and clinical research into the nature of comorbidities that promote cardiovascular illness. His primary research focus involves the impact of inhaled toxicants, especially common air pollutants, on vascular function and injury. He is currently the Director of the Mentored Career Development Program (KL2) in the Clinical Translational Science Center and Deputy Director of the new UNM Superfund Research Center. &nbsp;<br /><br />A link to his publications can be found here:&nbsp;https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=1Br2jtgAAAAJ&amp;hl=en&amp;oi=ao&nbsp;</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n734648790	Our laboratory is interested in the health effects of environmental toxins, with an emphasis on inhalation exposures leading to systemic health effects, such as cardiovascular disease. &nbsp;We are currently supported by several grants, which involve the following specific projects:<br /><br />1. Enhancement of Coronary Constriction by Volatile Organic Air Toxics: The goal of this project is to identify new pathways that mediate transference of air pollution toxicity to systemic vasculature that contributes to cardiovascular morbidity. &nbsp;We have primarily focused on serum-borne factors arising from lung responses as drivers of inflammatory endothelial activation. &nbsp;This project also entails our interests in what factors make inhaled particulates especially toxic, and we have a supplemental study with investigators at the University of Texas-El Paso (Hector Olvera, Ph.D.) to identify regional PM/gas contrasts and airshed compositions that may be specifically deleterious to human health.<br />2. Inhalation of Contaminated Mine Waste Dusts as a Route for Systemic Metal Toxicity. In this project, we are working collaboratively with investigators at UTEP and Michigan State University (Harkema, Wagner, and Morishita) to examine the systemic inflammatory repercussions of inhaled metal-rich particulate matter-derived from abandoned uranium mine sites throughout the Navajo Nation. &nbsp;This project involves on-site exposures to ambient particulates using a mobile laboratory, combined with lab-based toxicological comparisons and regional exposure modeling. &nbsp;<br />3. Systemic Health Implications of Occupational Nanomaterial Exposure. In partnership with Andrew Ottens, Ph.D., of Virginia Commonwealth University, we are examining the detailed molecular compositional changes in serum resulting from pulmonary nanomaterial exposure that lead to systemic toxicity. &nbsp;This study also partners with NIOSH scientists to comapre our findings from laboratory models with outcomes in an occupationally-exposed cohort.								mcampen@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

These "brain tsunamis" have been found to occur with relative frequency after stroke, traumatic brain injury, and hemorrhage. There are well documented deleterious effects in terms of stroke expansion and worsening of outcome. Therapies aimed at reducing these events or blocking the deleterious effects may be effective in improving outcomes in a wide range of patients with acute brain injury.&nbsp;			brain injury;cerebral blood flow;TBI;brain;stroke;vasospasm					andrewcarlson@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Jeremy	Chien	Chien, Jeremy	87131	Associate Professor in Division of Molecular Medicine		<p style="margin: 0in 0in 7pt; text-align: justify;">The primary objectives of my research program in <em>Applied Genomics and Cancer Therapeutics</em> (<strong>AGCT</strong>) are to crack the genetic codes of ovarian cancer, to understand the genetic basis of ovarian cancer, and to translate this knowledge into clinical applications to improve the early detection and the treatment of ovarian cancer. To support these objectives, my current research focuses on three areas: <strong>Cancer Genomics</strong>, <strong>Functional Genomics</strong>, and <strong>Precision Cancer Therapeutics</strong>.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n17714	My research program in <strong>Applied Genomics and Cancer Therapeutics</strong> focuses on three areas: <em>Cancer Genomics</em>, <em>Functional Genomics</em>, and <em>Precision Cancer Therapeutics</em>.<br /><br /><em>Cancer Genomics</em>: My research in this area focuses on the characterization of genetic mutations from cancer genomes to identify driver mutations and the development of experimental therapeutics to target driver genes in ovarian cancer.<br /><br /><em>Functional Genomics</em>: To translate the genetic information into biological insights and effective anti-cancer therapies, it is important to understand the effect of somatic mutations and develop drugs to exploit somatic mutations. Currently, we are performing functional genetic screens and selections to systematically characterize the effect of somatic mutations in specific cancer genes. The ultimate goal is to develop a catalog of mutations in specific cancer genes and identify drugs that can precisely target these mutations. This work is being funded by the American Cancer Society Research Scholar Grant (125618-RSG-14-067-01-TBE).<br /><br /><em>Precision Cancer Therapeutics</em>: The primary objective is to develop effective therapies for ovarian cancer.&nbsp; We are focusing on the unfolded protein response (UPR) pathway to induce cytotoxic effects in cancer cells.&nbsp; In particular, we are developing rational combination of novel therapeutics that target UPR pathway to induce immunogenic cell death and to enhance cisplatin sensitivity in ovarian cancer cells. This work is funded by the pending Department of Defense Ovarian Cancer Research Program (W81XWH-17-1-0078). 	Christine	Cogil	Cogil, Christine		Clinical Instructor I		<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 10pt;">As a young child I recognized that my mother was different because she walked with crutches as result of polio. It was then that my nursing vocation began.&nbsp; I obtained a BSN from Marymount College in Kansas and launched my career in a rural hospital as an ICU nurse. From there I expanded my horizons by working in the inner city with the Kansas City, Missouri Public Health Department.&nbsp; Then to Natchez, Mississippi where I did home health and hospice nursing for eleven years.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 10pt;">With a desire to grow professionally, I attended UNM in Albuquerque, New Mexico and received a MSN with a focus as Family Nurse Practitioner.&nbsp; I was fortunate to do my National Health Service Corp payback at a clinic on the U.S./Mexico border outside of El Paso, Texas.&nbsp; With a varied background in nursing, and a passion to serve the rural and medically underserved, I returned to UNM as a faculty member.<br /><br />Currently, I am working on a DNP at New Mexico State University.&nbsp; My focus is on the incorporation of oral health prevention and care into nursing practice.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n22618									ccogil@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Sally	Cohen	Cohen, Sally		Associate Professor		<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 10pt;">Innovations in initiatives that prepare nurses as leaders in health Sally Solomon Cohen is Associate Professor and Director, Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Nursing and Health Policy Collaborative at the University of New Mexico.&nbsp; Prior to that she was on the faculty of Yale University School of Nursing, where she founded and directed the Nursing Management Policy, and Leadership masters specialty, spearheaded the school&rsquo;s health policy focus in the PhD Program, and was on the Executive Committee of the Yale Interdisciplinary Center for Bioethics. She brings exceptional interdisciplinary expertise to education and research pertaining to nurses as leaders in health policy. Her research has focused on the politics of social policies for children, political development of nurses, relationships between nurse practitioners and managed care organization, dissemination of evidence to policymakers, and most recently, policies, communities and networks pertaining to bullying prevention programs for children. She is Deputy Editor for Policy, Politics, and Nursing Practice, has published widely in peer-reviewed nursing journals, and been a frequent presenter at the American Political Science Association. Dr. Cohen is an elected fellow of the American Academy of Nursing and the New York Academy of Medicine. She has a PhD from Columbia University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, MSN from Yale University, and BA from Cornell University.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2554									sscohen@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Linda	Cook	Cook, Linda	87131	Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1802	Dr. Cook is currently working on female hormonally-related cancers, namely ovarian, endometrial and breast cancer. Dr. Cook is the PI of a large National Institutes of Health multi-year grant investigating the mitochondrial DNA differences in several hundred women with and without ovarian cancer with her colleagues at UNM and in Canada.&#160; These genetic differences in the mitochondrial DNA could provide the basis for a screening test or possibly even a drug intervention. Other investigations using this resource include candidate SNP studies and novel risk factors for ovarian cancer (vitamin D/sunlight and herbicide exposures). She is also active in the international Ovarian Cancer Association Consortium (OCAC). Dr. Cook has completed an endometrial cancer tissue study and is currently investigating risk factors in women with microsatellite stable and microsatellite instable endometrial cancer. She is also investigating the underlying reasons for survival differences in Hispanic whites and non-Hispanic whites following an endometrial cancer diagnosis. She is a member of the international Epidemiology of Endometrial Cancer Consortium (E2C2). She is also the UNM PI on two projects in a NIH P50 grant with the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, WA. The goal of this P50 project is to investigate and reduce breast cancer disparities between Hispanic and non-Hispanic white women. She is particularly interested in the investigation of the occurrence and the subtypes of the aggressive forms of breast cancer in Hispanic women.&#160; Dr. Cook is also interested in developing a molecular epidemiology graduate training program at UNM. Albuquerque	Deborah	Altschul	Deborah Altschul, PhD	87131	Associate Professor		<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings> <o:AllowPNG /> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings> </xml><![endif]-->  <p class="MsoNormal">Dr. Altschul is a psychologist who is a faculty member at the University of New Mexico Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Science&rsquo;s Division of Community Behavioral Health. Her research is largely focused on examining the connection between behavioral health disparities, cultural competency, consumer outcomes, and evidence-based practice. Dr. Altschul works closely with the state&rsquo;s behavioral health authority, helping to develop a sustainable, culturally competent behavioral health infrastructure. She is the evaluation director of several federally funded grants supporting infrastructure development of behavioral health services in tribal communities. Prior to working in New Mexico, Dr. Altschul worked at the University of Hawai&lsquo;i Mental Health Services Research, Evaluation, and Training Program where she was the head of the Consumer Assessment Team, aimed at involving individuals with serious mental illness in study design, data collection, analysis, interpretation, and report writing. Dr. Altschul was also the cultural competency specialist on two federally funded grants focused on EBP implementation and statewide infrastructure development. She completed a postdoctoral fellowship with the National Association of State Mental Health Program Directors aimed at improving racial and ethnic disparities in mental health services.</p>  <!--[if 	Paulina	Deming	Deming, Paulina		Clinician Educator Associate Professor		Deming holds a BS in biology (1997) and a PharmD (2004) from the University of New Mexico. She completed a pharmacy practice residency and an infectious diseases pharmacotherapy residency at the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center. She joined UNM in 2007.  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Deming&rsquo;s research interests are in patient outcomes during chronic hepatitis C virus therapy, including in patients with advanced liver disease and cirrhosis. She maintains a clinical practice specializing in HCV infections within the university-based HCV clinic, Truman Health Services HIV-HCV co-infection clinic, and Project ECHO (Extension for Community Healthcare Outcomes). She collaborates in research initiatives through Project ECHO and the Project ECHO HCV consortium and has co-authored position papers on the management of HCV infections for professional pharmacy groups.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n24117237									PDeming@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

ALbuquerque	Vojo	Deretic	Deretic, Vojo	87131	Professor and Chairman		<p>Dr. Deretic is Director of the NIH-funded Autophagy, Inflammation, and Metabolism (AIM) Center of Biomedical Research Excellence.&nbsp; AIM&nbsp;is a nationally, internationally, and locally important center for advancement of research on autophagy in disease. It is an intellectual and technological hub for autophagy and its intersections with inflammation and metabolism in a full spectrum of diseases. It endows the state of New Mexico and the region with a cutting edge biomedical center of excellence while giving the nation a resource for both basic science and for development of new approaches in treating a wide spectrum of disease. AIM supports both junior and senior investigators through multi-year projects and pilots and aims to grow into an internationally known center by its scientific output and impact. AIM will host national and international activities, promote collaborations, and will provide career opportunities at many levels. The AIM center is funded by NIH grant P20GM121176.</p>  <p>Learn more about the AIM center:</p>  <ul>  <li>Twitter:&nbsp;<a href="https://twitter.com/AIM_autophagy">https://twitter.com/AIM_autophagy</a></li>  <li>Facebook:&nbsp;<a href="https://www.facebook.com/AIMAutophagy/">https://www.facebook.com/AIMAutophagy/</a></li>  <li><a href="https://mgm.unm.edu/aim-center/index.html" title="AIM Center">Autophagy, Inflammation, and Metabolism (AIM) Center Website</a></li>  <li><a href="https://www.autophagy.center/">AIM site for international affiliates and events</a></li>  </ul>  <p>Dr. Deretic's main contributions to science come from studies by his team on the role of autophagy in infection and immunity. Autophagy, a cytoplasmic pathway for the removal of damaged or surplus organelles, has been previously implicated in cancer, neurodegeneration, development, and aging. Dr. Deretic's group is one of those that made the discovery that autophagic degradation is a major effector and aregulator of innate and adaptive immunity mechanisms for direct elimination of intracellular microbes. His current work is on the role of autophagy in immunity and inflammation, interactions with lipid metabolism, and fundamental mechanisms of how selective autophagy is regulated in mammalian cells.</p>  <p>For a link to a comprehensive review on autophagy in immunity click&nbsp;<strong><a href="http://www.nature.com/nri/journal/v13/n10/abs/nri3532.html">here</a></strong></p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n5961		New Mexico	MSC08 4660, 1 University of New Mexico	Autophagy	United States of America				VDeretic@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Darrell	Dinwiddie	Dinwiddie, Darrell		Assistant Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n9413	<p>The research focus of my lab is to use genomic medicine (a structured approach to disease diagnosis and management that prominently features next-generation sequencing and analysis at a genome scale) to diagnose, discover, and investigate rare monogenic genetic disorders and to apply genomics to understand immune-mediated disorders.&nbsp;</p>  <p><strong>Rare Genetic Diseases</strong></p>  <p>My research has primarily focused on the development, validation, and analysis of clinical next-generation sequencing tests for the diagnosis of rare, monogenic, childhood disorders and implementation of research based tests to discover novel causes of genetic conditions.&nbsp; From 2011 to 2013 as the Director of Lab Operations for the <a href="http://www.childrensmercy.org/genomics/">Center for Pediatric Genomic Medicine at Children&rsquo;s Mercy Hospital &amp; Clinics in Kansas City, MO</a> my responsibilities included lead and manage the design, development, and deployment of sequence production workflows and quality control systems in support of the Center&rsquo;s operations to develop next generation sequencing based clinical tests. While at the Children&rsquo;s Mercy Hospital, my research contributed to enhancing the diagnostic capabilities of genomic testing for infants displaying symptoms of monogenetic (or rare) genetic diseases.&nbsp; I was part of the team that developed and validated a clinical next-generation sequencing diagnostic test that targets 552 genes known to cause rare childhood-onset disease. The test has subsequently been <a href="http://www.illumina.com/clinical/translational_genomics/product/trusight_inherited_disease.ilmn">licensed by Illumina&reg;.</a> In addition, I was also a co-first author of a proof of principle study published in <i>Science Translational Medicine</i> that demonstrated the feasibility of 50 hour whole genome sequencing and analysis in the neonatal intensive care unit at Children&rsquo;s Mercy Hospital to assist in the diagnosis of rare diseases.&nbsp; This research was featured in the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/04/health/new-test-of-babies-dna-speeds-diagnosis.html"><i>New York Times</i></a> and <a href="http://healthland.time.com/2012/12/04/top-10-health-lists/slide/speeding-dna-based-diagnosis-for-newborns/"><i>TIME</i></a> as being one of the first promising clinical uses of genomic medicine. &nbsp;At the University of New Mexico my lab will continue to push next-generation sequencing into the clinic to investigate rare genetic disorders.&nbsp;</p>  <p><strong>Immnogenomics</strong></p>  <p>My lab also uses genomics to research and understand immune function in humans. Current studies include investigating the cause of primary immunodeficiencies, and investigating the role of genetics in the susceptibility to and clearance of infections, and the development and progression of immune-mediated disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease.&nbsp; My lab uses exome and genome sequencing to discover the genetic cause of novel and atypical primary immunodeficiencies.&nbsp; For example, we were able to discover mutations in the gene <i>PLDN</i> as a cause of a Hermansky-Pudlak-like primary immunodeficiency syndrome and a described in one family how combined mutations in two genes, <i>DOCK8</i> and <i>CLEC7A</i> produced an atypical immunodeficiency.&nbsp; Additional studies in my lab are investigating the role of genetics in the susceptibility to and progression of sepsis and the childhood onset inflammatory bowel disease.</p>								dldinwiddie@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Melanie	Dodd	Dodd, Melanie A		Vice Chair &amp; Clinician Educator Associate Professor		Dodd received a BS in Pharmacy from Purdue University in 1994 and a PharmD from the University of New Mexico in 1997. She completed at Pharmacy Practice Residency at Presbyterian Healthcare Services in Albuquerque, NM in 1998.  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Dodd&rsquo;s research focuses on the development, implementation and impact of new pharmacist clinical practice models, including interprofessional teams, on patient outcomes. Dodd is an expert in the area of geriatric pharmacotherapy and is a pharmacist clinician with prescriptive authority at the UNM Senior Health Clinic, providing chronic disease and medication management for older adults. She also has an interest in the scholarship of innovative teaching methods with a focus on geriatric interprofessional education. Her research has focused on the development and impact of new clinical practice models involving the pharmacist as an essential member of the team, including pharmacists in advanced roles such as the pharmacist clinician.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1339148960									MDodd@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

gte mso 10]>  <style>   /* Style Definitions */  table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:10.0pt;   font-family:"Times New Roman";}  </style>  <![endif]--> <!--StartFragment-->  <p class="MsoNormal">I have worked at the interface of biology, bioinformatics, and engineering since the beginning of my scientific career.&nbsp; My graduate advisor was Dr. Bernhard Palsson, where I was the first person to take genome sequence information and develop predictive mathematical models of bacterial metabolism.&nbsp; My research started a significant global effort and many papers from my graduate work have over 800 citations.&nbsp; My graduate work sparked an intense interest in genomics technology, and thus I worked with Dr. George Church at Harvard Medical School for my post-doctoral studies.&nbsp; I have worked on the development of genome technologies since that time.&nbsp; Now, my laboratory is in the NCI designated Cancer Research and Treatment Center at the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center.&nbsp; I have a very active group of engineers, biologists, and chemists, all working together toward the development of ultrahigh-throughput DNA sequencing technology and computational biology.&nbsp; The move to the UNM in 2005 was ideal since I was born and raised in Albuquerque, NM.</p>  <!--EndFragment-->		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2674				Systems Biology;genomics;Spatial temporal modeling, epidermal growth factor receptor, functional genomics technologies, polony sequencing;DNA;DNA sequencing					JSEdwards@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Esther	Erdei	Erdei, Esther		Research Assistant Professor		<p>Erdei received a PhD in Immunology from Lorand Eotvos University in Budapest, Hungary, in 2003 and a Master of Public Health from the University of New Mexico in 2010.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Dr. Erdei has been working on public health problems for her entire scientific career. She is an expert in molecular epidemiology, immunology, autoimmune molecular markers and environmental health research involving air pollution and health effects, asthma research and immune system responses during pregnancy and early childhood associated with metal exposures. Her research focuses on integrating benchtop immunology research with community participatory research approaches among underserved and underrepresented communities in the United States, Latin America and Europe. Her recent works are centered on various immunological effects of chronic, low-level exposures to uranium, mercury and other heavy metal in tribal community members in the Southwest and Midwest of United States.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n527981467									EErdei@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

ALBUQUERQUE	Hua-Ying	Fan	Fan, Hua-Ying	87131	Associate Professor of Molecular Medicine		The Fan lab is interested in understanding the mechanisms of epigenetic regulation, focusing on two main directions: (1) the function and regulation of ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers, and (2) the mechanisms of mitotic transcription memory by the retention of sequence-specific transcription factors on mitotic chromatin. Results from these studies will shed light on fundamental mechanisms of epigenetic regulation and provide novel insights into the causes and mechanisms of table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:12.0pt;   font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;   mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;   mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;   mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;   mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;}  </style>  <![endif]--> <!--StartFragment-->  <p class="MsoNormal">The Fan lab is interested in understanding the mechanisms of epigenetic regulation, focusing on two main directions.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal"><strong>I. Functions and regulations of ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers</strong></p>  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .5in;">We are interested in understanding the mechanisms by which chromatin structure is regulated and how defects in chromatin structure regulation can lead to disease, including cancer. A major focus of our research has been aimed at understanding the mechanisms by which ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers regulate chromatin structure and how the biochemical activities of these enzymes are used to carry out diverse biological process, such as transcription regulation and DNA repair. ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers use energy from ATP hydrolysis to alter DNA-protein contacts, typically those between DNA and histones. Our work has made significant insights into remodeling mechanisms and regulation as well as the underlying causes of disease.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .5in;">Mutations in the CSB remodeler lead to Cockayne syndrome: a devastating premature aging disorder associated with numerous developmental and neurological defects. There are more than 30 known and predicted ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers in humans; CSB, however, is the only remodeler that is essential for transcription-coupled DNA repair (TCR), a process that rapidly removes transcription-stalling DNA lesions. Moreover, CSB is critical for relieving oxidative stress. We have made significant advances in understanding how this chromatin remodeler is uniquely equipped to carry out its functions. (1) The association of CSB with chromatin is tightly regulated. In general, only 10% of CSB is chromatin bound, but upon UV irradiation or oxidative stress, more than 90% of CSB becomes chromatin associated; this is in stark contrast to other, well-studied remodelers such as SWI/SNF and ISWI that are constitutively bound to chromatin. (2) Using separation-of-function derivatives, we have demonstrated that the chromatin remodeling activity of CSB is essential for its function in transcription-coupled DNA repair (TCR). (3) The chromatin remodeling activity of CSB is tunable: CSB, on its own, displays weak remodeling activity (~20-fold less than SWI/SNF or ACF). Strikingly, together with NAP1-like histone chaperones, CSB remodels chromatin robustly, to a level similar to SWI/SNF or ACF. (4) CSB interacts with the CTCF protein and through this interaction becomes significantly enriched at CTCF binding sites upon oxidative stress. Given that CTCF is a key player in regulating higher- order chromatin-structure, CSB may collaborate with CTCF to reorganize chromatin structure in response to oxidative stress to facilitate coordinated gene expression or efficient DNA repair. We are exploiting these unique properties of CSB to understand how this ATP-dependent chromatin remodeler is uniquely equipped to protect cells from genotoxic stress. Moreover, this work may shed new light on the causes and mechanism of Cockayne syndrome.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal"><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>  <p class="MsoNormal"><strong>II. </strong><strong>Mechanisms of mitotic transcription memory by mitotic bookmarking factors.</strong></p>  <p class="MsoNormalCxSpMiddle" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .5in;">We are also interested in unraveling the epigenetic mechanisms that maintain cell identity through mitosis. During the journey a zygote takes to become the greater than 200 specialized cell types that make up the human body, numerous cell divisions occur. Lineage commitment demands that specific transcription programs be maintained through these cell divisions with high fidelity to preserve cell identity. During mitosis, transcription ceases and the vast majority of the transcriptional regulatory machinery dissociates from the highly condensed chromatin. Intriguingly, specific transcription programs are propagated through mitosis and faithfully passed on to daughter cells. How then is the memory of a specific transcription program propagated through cell division? Accumulating evidence indicates that select transcription factors that are endowed with the capacity to remain associated with mitotic chromatin likely play critical roles in maintaining transcriptional memory through cell division. The unique properties that permit these transcription factors to remain associated with mitotic chromatin, their precise functions in transcriptional memory maintenance, and the mechanisms that regulate their occupancy sites during cell-fate specification remain poorly understood. Answers to these questions are essential to understand the underlying mechanisms that orchestrate the inheritance of transcription programs through mitosis and, thus, maintain cell identity, a fundamental question of developmental biology.</p>  <p class="MsoNormalCxSpMiddle" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .5in;">Notch signaling is central to development, and aberrant Notch signaling has been associated with developmental abnormalities and cancer. Little is known about the epigenetic mechanisms by which transcriptional programs established by Notch signaling are propagated through cell division to maintain cell identity.&nbsp;Our recent work has demonstrated that RBPJ, the major transcriptional effector of the Notch signaling pathway, can remain associated with mitotic chromatin. We also discovered that genes bound by RBPJ during mitosis exhibit an earlier requirement of RBPJ for their transcription reactivation upon mitotic exit. We are using Notch-signaling effector RBPJ as a model protein to investigate the epigenetic regulation of cell identity maintenance through the mitotic chromatin.</p>  <!--EndFragment-->	New Mexico	2325 Camino De Salud NE	Cancer Genetics, Epigenetics and Genomics	United States of America				hufan@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Amy	Gardiner	Gardiner, Amy						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n10923	<p>My research is focused on understanding the role of non-coding RNAs and RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) in neuronal development, substance abuse, and cancer. Small non-coding RNAs, such as microRNAs (miRNAs), and RBPs post-transcriptionally control the expression of a vast number of neuronal genes through the regulation mRNA splicing, stability, localization, and translation. Many miRNAs and RBPs are therefore considered to be master regulators of gene expression. Much of my work has concentrated on defining the regulatory regions and mechanisms that direct these processes. Current projects in my lab involve uncovering novel mechanisms of small RNA-mediated regulation of gene expression, examining miRNA-mediated pathways during cortical vascular development, and investigating the role of both small and long non-coding RNAs in glioblastoma multiforme.</p>  <p>1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; miR-150 is a well-characterized miRNA that is expressed in the brain, and specifically in endothelial cells, during development. miR-150 is a known regulator of angiogenesis, and it is upregulated in the developing cortex in our model of prenatal alcohol exposure. We are working to identify angiogenic targets of miR-150 and to determine its effect on the developing cortical vasculature during prenatal alcohol exposure.</p>  <p>2)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; KSRP is an RBP whose expression is significantly associated with prolonged survival of glioblastoma patients. We have identified novel KSRP-regulated miRNA and long non-coding RNA targets in the cortex. Ongoing studies are aimed at understanding how KSRP interacts with and regulates its various targets in glioblastoma cells and elucidating its tumor suppressive effect in a genetically engineered mouse model of glioblastoma.&nbsp;</p>								AGardiner@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	William	Garver	Garver, William "Sherm"		Assistant Professor		<p class="western" style="margin-bottom: 0.14in;">&nbsp;William Garver received his PhD from New Mexico State University (1991). He performed his postdoctoral fellowship in the Department of Metabolism, Endocrinology, and Nutrition at the University of Washington Health Sciences Center (1992-1994). He then served as a research professor in the Department of Biochemistry and Pediatrics at the University of Arizona Health Sciences Center (1995-2009) before joining the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology at the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center (2010-present).</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7139	<p class="western" style="margin-bottom: 0.14in;">My general interest is in the field of nutritional and metabolic biochemistry with a focus on the transport and homeostasis of lipids. For several years I have investigated the Niemann-Pick C1 (NPC1) gene and protein. The NPC1 protein has a central role in regulating the transport of low density lipoprotein (LDL)-derived cholesterol and fatty acids from late endosomes to various cellular compartments, including the plasma membrane for efflux and formation of high density lipoproteins (HDL). It is well known that genetic variation of the NPC1 gene is responsible for a rare autosomal-recessive lipid storage disease characterized by liver dysfunction and progressive neurological degeneration. However, our studies have also demonstrated that genetic variation of the NPC1 gene is associated with disparate metabolic diseases (obesity, insulin resistance, diabetes mellitus) which have reached epidemic proportions worldwide.</p>								WGarver@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Charles	Gasparovic	Gasparovic, Charles	87131	Director, Spectroscopy Core<br />		<p>Underlying all brain activity is biochemistry. Genes get expressed to make  proteins, which, in turn, make everything else in the brain. This includes cell  membranes and the energy substrates, neurotransmitters, synaptic receptors, and  ion pumps that are directly involved in the transmission of neural signals.&nbsp; At  MRN, we use our magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanners to study brain  chemistry in many different disorders, applying a technique known as magnetic  resonance spectroscopy (MRS).</p>  <p>The use of MRS to study chemistry was actually the first application of  magnetic resonance, decades before the invention of MRI. When proton MRS is used  to study neurochemistry, a &ldquo;spectrum&rdquo; of magnetic resonance signals is obtained  that shows the regional levels of several important brain metabolites. These  include the brain&rsquo;s major neurotransmitters glutamate and GABA, the energy  metabolites creatine and phosphocreatine, and a chemical known as N-acetyl  aspartate (NAA), found only in neurons and therefore used as a marker of  neuronal health.</p>  <p>Dr. Gasparovic's primary expertise and research interest in the last few  decades have been in the application of MRS to study brain biochemistry. In the  last decade at MRN, he has been involved in MRS studies on several disorders,  including traumatic brain injury, vascular dementia, alcohol abuse,  schizophrenia, neurodevelopment, and normal cognition (intelligence and  creativity).</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n4221		New Mexico	Department of Psychology, MSC03 2220, 1 University of New Mexico	Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy of schizophrenia;Vascular dementia;Traumatic brain injury;Neurodevelopment;Normal cognition (intelligence and creativity);Alcohol abuse	United States of America				chuck@unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Melissa	Gonzales	Gonzales, Melissa	87131	Associate Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n5226	Dr. Gonzales is the Director of the Environmental Health (EH)&nbsp;Core&nbsp;in the New Mexico CARES Health Disparities Center,&nbsp;which&nbsp;builds on and expands the existing relationships between communities, policy makers, UNM researchers and physicians and nurses across NM to develop, implement, and sustain effective intervention strategies.&nbsp;The objective of the core is&nbsp;to shift from studying environmental health problems to creating effective and sustainable solutions to reduce environmental health disparities among New Mexico&rsquo;s large and diverse Hispanic and Native American populations.&nbsp; Dr. Gonzales also&nbsp;has an active research program in&nbsp;colorectal cancer prevention.&nbsp; She&nbsp;is the PI and working collaboratively with&nbsp;Dr. Richard Hoffman and Dr. Ashwani Rajput&nbsp;on&nbsp;the Colorectal Disease Prevention Study, which examines&nbsp;colorectal cancer patients' risk and cancer screening patterns.&nbsp; This study builds on her published research on results of the New Mexico Behavioral Risk Factors Surveillance survey (BRFSS).&nbsp; Her analysis&nbsp;indicates that&nbsp;New Mexico&nbsp;Hispanics&nbsp;are&nbsp;less likely than non-Hispanic Whites to&nbsp;be in compliance with&nbsp;colorectal cancer screening guidelines, while having&nbsp;a&nbsp;higher prevalence of CRC-related risk factors including diabetes.&nbsp; In addition, Dr. Gonzales is&nbsp;the Assistant Director of the&nbsp;UNM Preventive Medicine Residency Program, where she has been an integral part of developing&nbsp;an innovative general preventive medicine and public health residency&nbsp;curriculum emphasizing the&nbsp;unique health needs of&nbsp;New Mexico.	New Mexico	Division of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Preventive Medicine, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				MGonzales@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Nina	Gonzales	Gonzales, Nina						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n19605										thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Laura	Gonz&#225;lez Bosc	Gonzalez Bosc, Laura V	87131	Professor		<p>I have a broad background in physiology, with specific training and expertise in vascular physiology, gene expression regulation, vascular inflammation, vascular reactivity and vascular phenotypic changes.&nbsp;</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7399	<p>My research interest is on defining the mechanisms by which hypoxia alters vascular smooth muscle (VSMC) phenotype. Long-term hypoxia results from residence at high altitude, chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD), and sleep apnea. COPD and sleep apnea are established major causes of mortality and morbidity in the U.S. and world-wide. COPD is currently the third leading cause of death in the U.S. with more than 11 million people diagnosed with the condition. Sleep apnea, on the other hand, is a breathing disorder that affects an estimated one in five adults in the U.S. and is also a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, including pulmonary hypertension (PH). We use two animal models of hypoxia: chronic hypobaric hypoxia (CH), which causes hypertension within the lungs (PH, model of COPD or high altitude) and intermittent hypercarbic/hypoxia (IH, model of sleep apnea), which causes systemic hypertension. We have been focusing in the role of the calcium-regulated transcription factor NFAT (nuclear factor of activated T cells) in each of these models. NFAT is a cytosolic phosphorylated protein. Increases in intracellular calcium activate the phosphatase calcineurin leading to NFAT dephosphorylation and nuclear import. We have demonstrated that exposing mice to hypoxia, either chronic or intermittent, causes NFAT activation in the smooth muscle of the pulmonary and systemic vasculature, respectively.</p>  <p>We identified a novel mechanism that regulates NFATc3 activation in PASMC. CH increases superoxide (<sup>&bull;</sup>O<sub>2</sub><sup>&minus;</sup>) and reduces H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, in part, by decreasing superoxide dismutase 1 activity and expression. Decreased H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> activates acid sensing ion channel 1 (ASIC1) forming a complex with calcineurin B facilitated by the scaffolding protein interacting with C kinase (PICK-1). ASIC1 can initiate NFATc3 signaling by increasing intracellular Ca<sup>2+</sup> thereby activating calcineurin, which dephosphorylates NFATc3. The macromolecular complex of ASIC1/calcineurin B/PICK-1 interacts with the cytoskeleton allowing the calcineurin/NFATc3 complex to be imported into the nucleus. At the same time, the increased <sup>&bull;</sup>O<sub>2</sub><sup>&minus;</sup> activates RhoA/rho kinase leading to actin polymerization and enhanced trafficking of the calcineurin/NFATc3 complex to the nucleus. Once in the nucleus, we found that in PASMC, NFATc3 contributes to the early proliferative response to hypoxia followed by re-differentiation through upregulation of guanylyl cyclase &alpha;1 and smooth muscle &alpha;-actin by <i>trans</i>-activating their promoters. Therefore, NFATc3 promotes pulmonary arterial remodeling and contractility, contributing to the development of pulmonary hypertension in response to CH.</p>  <p>In collaboration with Dr. Kanagy, we have demonstrated that NFATc3 is required for IH-induced systemic hypertension and mesenteric arterial remodeling. Also, our unpublished observations (manuscript under review) suggest that a reduction in NFATc3 activity in endothelial cells in response to IH exposure causes a reduction in the expression of cystathionine &gamma;-lyase (CSE)-derived hydrogen sulfide (H<sub>2</sub>S). Impaired H<sub>2</sub>S signaling in the systemic vasculature contributes to IH-induced systemic hypertension.</p>  Since NFATc3 is the main orchestrator of the adaptive immune response, we became interested in determining the role of the adaptive immune system in CH-induced PH. Our recent data suggest a direct causal link between CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells and PH under hypoxic conditions, specifically pointing to T<sub>H</sub>17 cells. Our results also show that CH increases perivascular T<sub>H</sub>17 cells localization, a response that is prevented by an inhibitor of RORg&tau;, the signature nuclear receptor for T<sub>H</sub>17 cells and suggest a role for these cells in PASMC proliferation and migration leading to pulmonary arterial remodeling. <br />We are also studying which are the neo- or self-antigens that drive this T<sub>H</sub>17-mediated inflammatory response.<br /><br />In addition, we are currently working on a pilot project aimed to determine the role of IL-6 trans-signaling in the development of proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR). This project is in collaboration with Dr. Joaquin Tosi, Ophthalmologist at the Department of Surgery at UNM Hospital.<br /><br />	New Mexico	MSC084750	pulmonary vasculature;hypertension;Vascular;Transcriptional control;Physiology;smooth muscle	United States of America				lgonzalezbosc@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Ajna	Hamidovic	Hamidovic, Ajna		Assistant Professor		<p>Hamidovic received a PharmD from the University of Wisconsin in 2002 and an MS in Clinical Investigation from Northwestern University in 2007.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Hamidovic&rsquo;s research focuses on developing novel pharmacological treatments for smoking cessation. Her Clinical and Experimental Drug Addiction Research Lab evaluates intranasal insulin for its efficacy in reducing cravings, improving cognitive function and reducing snack intake during smoking cessation. The lab actively uses tests of memory and cognition, eating behavior, stress reactivity and metabolic processing to analyze efficacy of CNS insulin in increasing smoking abstinence rates. Clinical measures collected in the lab include safety assessments of endocrine and olfactory neurological parameters. She holds two Investigational New Drug Approvals by the FDA to evaluate novel pharmacological approaches for smoking cessation.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1568	Our lab is interested in evaluating safety and efficacy of intranasal  insulin in relieving cognitive deficits during withdrawal from abused  drugs. We also conduct research in genetics of drug addiction. We have  identified genetic variants that predict behavioral, cognitive and mood  effects of amphetamine in humans. Our more recent work has contributed  to identifying genomic loci that mediate smoking persistence in African  Americans.								ahamidovic@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
