<w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading" /> </w:LatentStyles> </xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 10]>  <style>   /* Style Definitions */   table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin-top:0in;   mso-para-margin-right:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;   mso-para-margin-left:0in;   line-height:115%;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:11.0pt;   font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";   mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;   mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;   mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;   mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;   mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";   mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}  </style>  <![endif]-->		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n6800		New Mexico	Department of Radiology, MSC10 5530, 1 University of New Mexico	Cerebral Cavernous Malformations	United States of America				BHart@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Rebecca	Hartley	Hartley, Rebecca		Associate Professor		<strong>Rebecca S. Hartley, Ph.D.</strong> is an Associate Professor of Cell Biology and Physiology at the University of New Mexico School of Medicine and a Member of the UNM Cancer Center. She earned her BS in Biology, also from the University of New Mexico, and her doctorate in Biological Structure (Anatomy) from the University of Washington in 1992, studying the developmental origin of adult skeletal muscle stem cells. Professor Hartley completed her postdoctoral studies at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center and the University of Rennes, France. During this time she began studies on developmental regulation of the embryonic cell cycle, focusing first on post-translational and then post-transcriptional regulatory mechanisms. In1998, she joined the faculty at the University of Iowa where her group described zygote-mediated deadenylation of maternal cyclin mRNAs as a key mechanism of embryonic cell cycle remodeling. Prof. Hartley received a March of Dimes Basil O&#8217;Connor Award and an American Cancer Society Research Scholar Award for this work. She continued these studies with an NIH-NCI R01 after her move back home to New Mexico; collaborating with Professors James Dahlberg and Elsebet Lund to show that a zygote transcribed microRNA mediates maternal cyclin deadenylation. Her studies of the <em>Xenopus laevis</em> embryonic cell cycle led directly to her current studies on post-transcriptional regulation of the breast cancer cell cycle. Prof. Hartley&#8217;s work has shown that the RNA binding proteins and microRNAs that regulate maternal cyclins are deregulated in breast cancer cells, leading to cyclin overexpression and cell cycle disruption.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n6134	<p>The goal of our laboratory is to define post-transcriptional mechanisms of cell cycle regulation in the early embryonic cell cycle of <em>Xenopus laevis</em> and in the cancer cell cycle. We study RNA binding proteins and microRNAs, post-transcriptional regulators responsible for regulating the early embryonic cell cycle, and whose expression is disrupted in cancer. Specifically, we are assessing the role of Human antigen R (HuR), cold-inducible RNA binding protein (CIRP) and microRNAs in co-reulating targets implicated in breast cancer etiology.</p>  <p>The long term goal of the Principal Investigator's laboratory is to understand how the cell cycle is regulated during the development of a multicellular organism. Ultimately, we wish to apply this knowledge to developing novel therapies for cancer and genetic diseases. Towards this goal, we are analyzing gap phase and checkpoint addition to the mitotic cell cycles of Xenopus laevis. Gap phases (G1 and G2) are important periods in the adult somatic cell cycle during which correct replication and division of the chromosomes are ensured. The first gap phase (G1) is also when cells grow, and either commit to another round of cell division or exit the cell cycle, to become quiescent or differentiate. Xenopus laevis embryonic cell cycles lack G phases. The first 12 rapid and synchronous divisions alternate between DNA synthesis and mitosis, and are driven by maternal mRNAs and proteins stored in the egg. The cell cycle remodels after the twelfth divison, lengthening as G phases are added during the switch from maternal to zygotic control of development, the maternal to zygotic transition (MZT). After the MZT in Xenopus, an increase in the length of S-phase extends cycles 13 and 14. Cycle 15 resembles a typical adult somatic cell cycle, with G1 and G2 phases. Cell cycle times now range from 3 to 6 hours, differing for subpopulations of cells in specific regions of the embryo. This natural process of G phase and checkpoint addition to the cell cycle is the converse of the pathway normal cells traverse in becoming cancer cells. Thus, cell cycle remodeling (lengthening due to G phase addition) provides a unique opportunity to study the establishment of controls in a normal and homogeneous cell population. Insight into this process may lead to novel strategies not only to combat uncontrolled cell division, but to prevent mutations leading to neoplastic and malignant states. In addition, identification of novel regulatory mechanisms will result in a better understanding of how the acquisition of a regulated cell cycle is integrated with development.</p>  <p>The mechanism of G-phase addition is unknown, but cell cycle remodeling is associated with dramatic changes in cell cycle regulators. We are studying the mechanisms of these changes. Maternal cyclins and cyclin dependent kinases (cdks), like their somatic counterparts, drive progression through the cell cycle. In somatic cell cycles, cyclin E is synthesized during G1, and cyclin E/Cdk2 kinase activity is rate limiting for progression through S phase, after which cyclin E is degraded. Unlike somatic cycles, in embryonic cycles cyclin E1 is present at constant levels, until it is degraded after the twelfth cell cycle, at the MZT. We believe that constant levels of cyclin E1 during the first 12 cycles eliminate G1 phase, and its degradation is necessary for the addition of G1 after the MBT. We are currently determining the mechanism of cyclin E1 stability during the early cycles, as well as its degradation at the MZT using both in vivo expression and in vitro degradation assays. Degradation of maternal cyclins A1 and B2 follows that of cyclin E1, as does the upregulation of zygotic cyclin A2 and Xic1. Cyclin A2 is the Xenopus homolog of somatic cyclin A, and Xic1 is a member of the p27 family of cyclin dependent kinase inhibitors that specifically inhibits cyclin E/Cdk2. Injection of Xic1 before the MZT lengthens the mitotic cell cycles, and delays the degradation of maternal cyclins and the MZT. These results suggest that cyclin E1/Cdk2 regulates cell cycle length and remodeling, as well as the timing of the MZT. We are testing whether the changes in gene expression that occur during cell cycle remodeling are dependent on repression of cyclin E1/Cdk2.</p>  <p>In addition, we are determining the role of translational control in modulating expression of cyclins and cdk inhibitors during cell cycle remodeling. Current studies focus on identifying and isolating novel regulatory elements in the untranslated regions of mRNAs encoding cell cycle regulators and their interacting RNA-binding proteins. Using these approaches, translation of specific cell cycle proteins can be altered in vivo to determine the role of translational control in cell cycle regulation and remodeling. Linking translational control to cell cycle regulation will suggest pathways that may be altered during tumorigenesis as well as therapeutic targets.</p>								RHartley@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Richard	Harvey	Harvey, Richard C						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2091053462	<ul>  <li>Leukemia and Lymphoma</li>  <li>Molecular markers of disease</li>  <li>Gene expression signatures in cancer</li>  </ul>								RHarvey@unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Frederick	Hashimoto	Hashimoto, Frederick	87131	Professor Emeritus				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2880		New Mexico	Division of General Internal Medicine, DoIM MSC10 5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				FHashimoto@salud.unm.edu	thing;efac;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Catrin	Hasselgren	Hasselgren, Catrin						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n27802									chasselgren@unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Gary	Hatch	Hatch, Gary		Assistant Director Radiology-Pathology Center for Forensic Imaging				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7300									ghatch@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Helen	Hathaway	Hathaway, Helen J		Professor		<p><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>   <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>    <o:AllowPNG/>    <o:PixelsPerInch>96</o:PixelsPerInch>   </o:OfficeDocumentSettings> <![endif]--> <!--StartFragment--> <!--EndFragment--></p>  <p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-bottom: 15.6pt; margin-left: 0in; background: white; vertical-align: baseline;">My laboratory studies the molecular mechanisms by which epigenetic factors, hormone signaling, and the tissue microenvironment regulate normal reproductive biology, and cancer progression. &nbsp;We are particularly interested in the role of the G protein-coupled estrogen receptor, GPER, in female reproductive tract physiology, metabolism, and the etiology of women&rsquo;s cancers, including endometrial, ovarian, and breast cancer.&nbsp; We have also established collaborations with physicists and chemists, and together we are investigating the use of novel magnetic nanoparticles and imaging modalities to detect and treat cancer with high sensitivity and selectivity.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n3358	<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>   <o:OfficeDocumentSettings> <w:LsdException Locked="false" SemiHidden="true" UnhideWhenUsed="true"     Name="Smart Hyperlink"/>   </w:LatentStyles>  </xml><![endif]--> <!--[if gte mso 10]>  <style>   /* Style Definitions */  table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:10.0pt;   font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;}  </style>  <![endif]--> <!--StartFragment-->  <p class="p1">The goal of my research is to dissect the mechanisms by which cells respond to environmental cues, and how those interactions are altered during the progression from normal to neoplastic disease in women&rsquo;s cancers. &nbsp;A major focus of my laboratory is the study of the novel G protein-coupled estrogen receptor, GPER (also known as GPR30). &nbsp;A multidisciplinary collaborative effort is the best approach to solve complex biological problems, and through a successful collaboration with Dr. Eric Prossnitz, we established several models crucial to dissect GPER function. &nbsp;Using animal models my group defined a role for GPER in epithelial cell proliferation. Concomitantly we made the seminal observation that GPER-selective agonists and antagonists modulate GPER activity in vivo, paving the way for preclinical evaluation of these compounds in disease models. &nbsp;Moreover we have demonstrated that GPER promotes breast tumor proliferation and metastasis using genetically modified animal models of breast cancer and explant cultures of human breast tissue. &nbsp;These observations led my laboratory to make the intriguing discovery that estrogen, acting through GPER, alters the orientation of the mitotic spindle, which we are exploring using complex 3-dimensional culture models. &nbsp;These results have important implications with respect to fundamental principles of cell division control and morphogenesis in estrogen-responsive tissues, and may lead to novel insights into the mechanisms by which estrogen promotes tumor progression. &nbsp;Another exciting area we are exploring relates to environmental estrogen mimics or xenoestrogens, chemicals in the environment and in foods that bind and activate estrogen receptors. &nbsp;The xenoestrogen bisphenol A (BPA) activates GPER along with the classical estrogen receptors, and we are exploring the consequences of BPA exposure during fetal life on breast development. &nbsp;<br /><br />Based on my expertise in breast neoplastic progression, I established new collaborations with a multidisciplinary team, including physicists, chemists, and clinician researchers, focused on developing novel methods to detect, target, and treat breast cancers. Using animal models, we are developing multifunctional magnetic nanoparticles (mNPs) that can be targeted to specific tumors, followed by application of an alternating magnetic field to the targeted mNPs to deliver localized heat, or thermal therapy. &nbsp;I led the effort that culminated in our first breast cancer-focused manuscript, which was published in Breast Cancer Research in October 2011. &nbsp;The findings were also featured in a press release.&nbsp;</p>  <!--EndFragment-->			cancer					HHathaway@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Deirdre	Hill	Hill, Deirdre	87131	Assistant Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2324	An important focus of my work is to develop greater understanding of the 1.6-fold increased risk of breast cancer death among Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic women in New Mexico, the largest known such disparity in Hispanics. As part of an NIH-funded R01, we are currently collecting extensive treatment information from the medical charts of over 2000 women to comprehensively address this question and identify possible prevention strategies. In addition, we are examining tumor aggressiveness markers, and assessing ancestry informative. Another important focus of my work is to understand benign breast conditions that may or may serve as precursors to breast cancer. I am following a cohort of women with premalignant breast disease (n=16,000) for breast cancer. Through examination of tissue biomarker expression in those that went on to cancer, vs. not, this study is poised to make a vital contribution to identification of women at short-term high-risk of breast cancer. Another important focus of my work is a series of collaborations within the Breast Cancer Surveillance Consortium (BCSC), which provide rich opportunities to contribute to the vital goals of optimizing breast cancer screening strategies, and improving radiologist interpretation of mammograms. As a co-investigator on the BCSC &#8220;Risk-Based Breast Cancer Screening in Community Settings&#8221;, an NIH PO1, I am overseeing assessment of mammography and MRI utilization in comparison with national guidelines. In the BCSC-initiated randomized clinical trial, &#8220;Strategies to Improve the Accuracy of Mammographic Interpretation I am working with BCSC investigators to evaluate the influence of several factors on intervention performance. As principal investigator of the NM Mammography Project, a BCSC effort that began in NM in 1992, I facilitate ongoing data analyses at the local and consortia level.	New Mexico	Division of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Preventive Medicine, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				DAHill@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Kent	Hutchison	Hutchison, Kent	87131	<p>Professor of Translational Neuroscience</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>		Dr. Hutchison has focused on medications and/or psychosocial interventions that  target the basic neurobiological and behavioral mechanisms that are involved in  the development and maintenance of addiction. To determine which individuals are  most vulnerable to addiction and to determine which individuals might benefit  most from a given treatment, he has focused on genetic factors that might  explain individual variation in the same basic neurobiological and behavioral  mechanisms that influence the etiology of addiction. These foci yield valuable  information about who may be most at risk for developing addiction, and valuable  information about who may be most likely to respond favorably to a given  treatment approach. Ultimately, matching individuals to treatment based on  specific genetic variables has the promise of increasing the overall  effectiveness of treatment approaches.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n14991		New Mexico	Department of Psychology, MSC03 2220, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				KHutchison@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Peter	Jensen	Jensen, Peter	87131-0001	Professor		<p>Jensen received his bachelor&rsquo;s degree in government from Harvard University in 1972. He completed both his master&rsquo;s degree (1976) and his dental degree (1979) at the University of Detroit (now Detroit Mercy). He completed his general practice residency training at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry/Strong Memorial Hospital in 1980. He then returned to the rural community in Nebraska where he grew up and maintained a private general dental practice until 1999. At that time, he became a faculty member in the Eastman Department of Dentistry at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, where he was director of the faculty practice until 2005.</p>  <p>Jensen joined UNM in June 2005. He has an appointment in both the Department of Dental Medicine and the College of Nursing.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Jensen has ongoing involvement in promoting interprofessional collaboration between dentistry and primary care in medicine as a way to improve access to oral health.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n31270		New Mexico	UNM Department of Dental Medicine, MSC 09 5020, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				pmjensen@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Rex	Jung	Jung, Rex E		Director of Neuropsychological Services		<p><strong>Dr. Jung</strong> studies both brain disease and what the brain does well&mdash;a field of research known as "positive neuroscience." His research is designed to relate behavioral measures, including intelligence, personality, and creativity, to brain function and structure in healthy, neurological, and psychiatric subjects. He has published over 80 research articles across a wide range of disciplines, including traumatic brain injury, lupus, schizophrenia, intelligence, and creativity.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1418716867				Normal cognition (intelligence and creativity);Neural substrates of intelligence					rex.jung@gmail.com	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Nancy	Kanagy	Kanagy, Nancy		Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n8081	<p>My primary research interests are vascular physiology, hypertension and blood pressure control. My current research focuses on altered signal transduction in vascular cells during the development and maintenance of hypertension. This involves studies in vascular smooth muscle cells, endothelial cells and arterial segments. The long-term goal of these investigations is elucidation of the mechanisms responsible for elevated vascular contractility in hypertension and the development of pharmacological tools to reverse this hypersensitivity.&nbsp;<br style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; font-size: 1em; outline: none;" /><br style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; font-size: 1em; outline: none;" />A major emphasis is investigating vascular effects of sleep apnea. We have developed a rat model of sleep apnea by exposing animals to intermittent hypoxia during their sleep period. Using this model, we have determined that the vasoactive peptide endothelin appears to initiate sustained hypertension (Kanagy et al 2001). We have also determined that 14 days of intermittent hypoxia initiates profound vascular changes that alter both endothelial function and vascular smooth muscle cell responses to endothelin. Ongoing studies are investigating the role of reactive oxygen species in these changes and deciphering the molecular mechanisms leading to augmented vasoconstriction to the endogenous peptide, endothelin.</p>  <p>A second ongoing project is investigating the cardiovascular effects of the environmental pollutant, diesel exhaust.&nbsp; We have found that even a short exposure to diesel exhaust causes profound alterations in coronary artery function and that repeated exposures initiate systemic alterations in both cardiac and vascular function.</p>  <p>We have recently been studying the contribution of hydrogen sulfide to the control of blood pressure and blood flow. &nbsp;These studies are exploring the site of synthesis of hydrogen sulfide, the mechanism of action in the vascular wall and the effect of intermittent hypoxia on the pathway.</p>			blood flow;endothelial;hypertension;signaling;Vascular					nkanagy@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Huining	Kang	Kang, Huining	87131	<p>Associate Professor</p>				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n166	Dr. Kang&rsquo;s primary research interest is statistical modeling and data analysis for high dimensional data including gene expression microarray data, SNP data, and next generation sequencing data. He is working with collaborators at the UNM Cancer Center and the Children&rsquo;s Oncology Group to develop and validate gene expression models used to improve risk classification, and predictions of outcome, therapeutic response, and relapse risk in childhood leukemia. He is a member of the Analytical Translational Genomics Group at UNM Cancer Center where he works on statistical methods for analyzing next generation sequencing data in cancer research. Another area of Dr. Kang&rsquo;s research is the statistical evaluation of biomedical tests with a focus on the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve. He has proposed a new form of ROC curve based on the generalized proportional odds-rate model, which has some advantages over the commonly used binormal form, and has developed the theory for related statistical inference. He is actively working with pathologists to evaluate the biomarkers in hematopathology.&nbsp; Dr. Kang is also interested in statistical applications in cancer epidemiology. He is currently working with epidemiologists to investigate factors related to the disproportionate breast cancer mortality in Hispanic as compared to non-Hispanic white women in New Mexico.	New Mexico	Division of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Preventive Medicine, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				HuKang@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Susan	Kellie	Kellie, Susan	87131	Professor		<p style="margin-top: 0.19in; margin-bottom: 0.19in; line-height: 100%;">Dr. Kellie&rsquo;s primary interests are within the field of hospital epidemiology include methicillin-resistant <em>S. aureus</em> (MRSA), <em>C. difficile, </em>and the implementation of hand hygiene and antimicrobial stewardship.</p>  <p style="margin-top: 0.19in; margin-bottom: 0.19in; line-height: 100%;">Fellows are offered the opportunity to spend a full month in hospital epidemiology and infection control and learn surveillance methodology, best practices and current guidelines in infection control, and participate in community-based activities in infection control when available. Fellows are encouraged to do outbreak investigations&nbsp; and participate in hospital quality improvement activities. This introduction to concepts of population health at the hospital level prepares fellows to design research projects in hospital epidemiology and infection control.</p>  <p style="margin-top: 0.19in; margin-bottom: 0.19in; line-height: 100%;">Recent research in which Dr. Kellie has mentored fellows included use of a clinical database to describe enhanced epidemiology of <em>Clostridium difficile</em> (presented at the Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America meeting 2011) and a survey of provider knowledge and attitudes about <em>C. difficile</em> (published in the American Journal of Infection Control in 2013). <br /><br />Current projects with fellows include investigating hand hygiene compliance in different settings using a new electronic surveillance tool.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n4175		New Mexico	Division of Infectious Diseases, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				SKellie@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Prakasha	Kempaiah	Kempaiah, Prakasha	87131	Associate Professor (Research)		Dr. Prakasha Kempaiah is a Associate Professor at the Center for Global Health(CGH), Department of Internal Medicine. Dr. Kempaiah received his PhD from the Institute for HumanGenetics, University of Goettingen, Germany. During his PhD dissertation, he worked on areas caused bygenetic disorders using animal models. Dr. Kempaiah's PhD thesis work on protein transduction domainmediated recombinant protein supplementation therapy for Rett-syndrome resulted in two disclosures beingfiled. He also has completed one year of certificate course in Clinical and Translational Research (CTR) at UNM with an emphasis on biostatistics, global health and clinical research. He is trained in the field of genetics, cell biology, biochemistry, animal models and infectious diseases with skills set in the areas of genetic diagnostics, cloning, cell culture, parasite culture, proteinexpression, flow cytometry, genotyping, functional genomics, genome wide association study (GWAS), geneexpression arrays, custom array design, high density data analysis, pathways network analysis andbiostatistics. Dr. Kempaiah is also well versed in using several genetics and genomics analysis tools such asSPSS, HPlus, Haploview, GeneSpring, Golden Helix SVS suite, GeneGo, analyzing genotypes, haplotypes,and high density GWAS and gene expression data. Dr. Kempaiah is an editorial board member of OpenJournal of Apoptosis, Human Parasitic Diseases, Journal of Life Medicine, AIMS Genetics, Asian Council ofScience Editors and Journal of Public Health &amp; Epidemiology. He is also an invited peer-reviewer for HumanParasitic Diseases, Gene Regulation and Systems Biology, Cancer Cell International,Breast Cancer,Biotechnology Progress, Journal of Cell Death, Immunology and Immunogenetics Insights, Gene Expression toGenetical Genomics and Cancer Informatics and other journals.&nbsp;<br />His research &nbsp;projects includes: (1), determining the relationship between the immunomodulatory aspect of immuneresponse genes and promoter polymorphism (SNPs and VNTRs), functional changes, downstream effects onmodulator production, and SMA manifestation; (2), determining the suitability of Glutamine as a therapeuticagent in children with malaria to target HSP70 production and improve the therapeutic effects of anti-malarialsin combination with glutamine; (3), GWAS using Illumina Omni-2.5 array, human Immunochip and wholegenome transcriptome arrays to identify important markers, CNVs and candidates gene pathways thatcondition development of SMA; (4), malaria parasite cultures for anti-malarial drug screening and to isolatehemozoin (PfHz) and testing its immunomodulatory activities using in-vitro cultures; (5), elucidating themolecular mechanisms of inflammatory-derived inefficient erythropoiesis using CD34+ hematopoieticprogenitor&rsquo;s cells isolated from umbilical specimens; (6), Identifying natural and pharmacological compoundsto stimulate inflammatory mediators altered during SMA such as interlukin-12 using in-vitro cultures treatedwith PfHz.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n550		New Mexico	Center for Global Health, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				PKempaiah@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

She served as faculty at the Minnesota residency program before joining the faculty of the University of New Mexico in January 1999. &nbsp;Dr. Kesler has the following leadership positions at UNM: Director, Center for Occupational and Environmental Health Promotion (COEHP); Program Director, Public Health and General Preventive Medicine Residency Program; Medical Director, UNMH Occupational Health Services.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n5411	<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Dr. Kesler is currently working on several areas of research interest within the area of preventive medicine. She oversees the Radiation Exposure Screening and Education Program which works with the community of former uranium miners.&nbsp; Dr. Kesler works with the New Mexico Department of Health on a project that is aimed at increasing the physician reporting of diagnosed occupational injuries and illnesses with the intent to use the data to direct prevention programs. Dr. Kesler also has interests that are educational based. She is program director of the UNM public health and general preventive medicine residency program. Associated with that responsibility, she currently has funding for the program itself and is pursuing additional funding related to providing innovative elements to the residency program.&nbsp; She is interested in assessing and improving the knowledge of primary care residents in preventive medicine topics such as obesity and nutrition with the intent of improving the general health of patients.</p>	New Mexico	Division of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Preventive Medicine, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				DKesler@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Yuko	Komesu	Komesu, Yuko	87131-0001	Associate Professor		I have had experience working with Dr. Ronald Schrader on the HRS Database and have become a facile user of its website. &#160;We have collaborated previously in reporting the 4-year cumulative incidence and remission of urinary incontinence in women in the HRS. &#160;This collaboration resulted in the publication of the manuscript, "Incidence and Remission of Urinary Incontinence in a Community Based Population of Women 50 Years", in the International Journal of Urogynecology and Pelvic Floor Dysfunction in February of 2009. &#160;This work also received the award as the Best Epidemiologic paper at the 29th Annual American Urogynecologic Society Meeting. &#160;This continued collaboration in the evaluation of UUI using unique mathematical approach to probability modeling will offer the opportunity to apply for future funding from the NIH based on pre-existing databases. &#160;<br /><br />I enjoy working with the patients who come to our sub-specialty clinic at the University of New Mexico Hospital and I feel fortunate to work with fabulous nurses, receptionists, administrative staff, midwives, and physical therapists that care deeply about our patients. &#160;I am lucky to be a member of a physician group which is one of the best in the nation.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n747	I am interested in caring for women with Pelvic Floor Disorders. &#160;I am particularly interested in the research and treatment of Urinary Incontinence, Overactive Bladder Syndrome and Pelvic Organ Prolapse. &#160;I am interested in the use of complimentary alternative medicine techniques and surgical techniques for treating Overactive Bladder Syndrome & Urinary Incontinence. &#160;	New Mexico	2211 Lomas Blvd. NE		United States of America					thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Konstantin	Konstantinov	Konstantinov, Konstantin	87131	Professor		<p class="MsoNormal">Dr. Konstantin N. Konstantinov completed his MD and PhD at the Academy of Medicine, Sofia. &nbsp;His medical and laboratory training in 3 different countries (Bulgaria, Denmark, and the US) led to a doctorate in Dermatology and Clinical Immunology, Board Certifications in three subspecialties (Dermatology, Internal Medicine, Rheumatology) and experience in basic immunology and translational clinical research. His work at The State Serum Institute, Copenhagen, The Autoimmune Disease Center at the Scripps Research Institute in La Jolla, California, and Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, shaped his career as a rheumatologist and autoimmune disease expert.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>  <p class="MsoNormal">In 2003 Dr. Konstantinov joined the University of New Mexico where now he is a Professor of Internal Medicine and Rheumatology. His clinical and research interests continue to focus on identification of novel autoantibodies and biomarkers for autoimmune diseases, the development of innovative diagnostic technologies, and the relationship of the autoimmune response to disease mechanisms. In 2016 he moved full-time to the VA Division of Rheumatology in Albuquerque, where he continues clinical work and teaching of medical and advance rheumatological training at all levels of professional education.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n4312		New Mexico	Division of Rheumatology, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				KKonstantinov@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Mary	Lacy	Lacy, Mary		Associate Professor, Department of Internal Medicine		<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Dr. Mary Lacy, MD, is an Associate Professor at the Department of Internal Medicine, Division of Hospital Medicine.&nbsp; She also serves as Director of High-Value Care. 	Robert	Lake	Lake, Robert				<p style="margin: 0px; font-stretch: normal; font-size: 12px; line-height: normal; font-family: Helvetica;">It is now generally accepted that cancer is associated with large-scale epigenetic changes. Epigenetics is the processes by which stable changes in gene expression occur without changes in the underlying DNA sequence. Epigenetic changes affect the way DNA is maintained, organized and interpreted. Our research focuses on understanding epigenetic regulatory mechanisms and how defects in these processes can lead disease such as cancer.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n29128				Cancer Genetics, Epigenetics and Genomics					rjlake@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Nicholas	Lam	Lam, Nicholas		Associate Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n12594										thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Christophe	Lambert	Lambert, Christophe G.		Associate Professor of Medicine		In August 2014 I became a faculty member in the University of New Mexico Center for Global Health, Division of Translational Informatics and Department of Internal Medicine. My research areas include clinical research informatics, bioinformatics, and systems thinking. My current research focus is analyzing longitudinal healthcare data for predictive and preventative medicine, in collaboration with other members of the <a href="http://www.ohdsi.org"> Observational Health Data Sciences and Informatics</a>&nbsp;program. The OHDSI/OMOP <a href="http://omop.org/CDM"> common data model</a>&nbsp;has been adopted to represent over 680M patients' electronic health and/or administrative claims records worldwide, enabling the development of a broad set of tools for the analysis of human health on these massive datasets. I am currently developing statistical and computational tools to compare treatment options and obtain better estimates of expected health outcomes despite large biases and confounding in the data, with a focus on bipolar disorder. In July 2016 I received an R21 award to research methods for observational comparative effectiveness research, and a <a href="http://www.pcori.org/research-results/2016/longitudinal-comparative-effectiveness-bipolar-disorder-therapies" title="PCORI award">PCORI award</a> to compare bipolar disorder treatments and outcomes in large scale administrative claims data. We are currently using a database of over 1 million bipolar disorder patients to answer questions about the safety and effectiveness of bipolar disorder therapies both short term and over many years of treatment.<br /><br />In addition I perform bioinformatic analyses of genomics datasets with current projects in pediatric Malaria in collaboration with Dr. DJ Perkins in the Center for Global Health, as well as projects analyzing the genetics of pediatric developmental delay, including Autism. This&nbsp;research builds on and continues nearly 15 years of analytic research in the genetic causes of disease performed during my tenure as founder and CEO of bioinformatics company&nbsp;<a href="http://www.goldenhelix.com">Golden Helix</a>.&nbsp;I founded the company in 1998 in Bozeman, MT. Golden Helix software and services empowers scientists to accelerate research productivity, determine the genetic causes of disease, facility genetic testing, develop diagnostics and advance the quest for personalized medicine. Serving hundreds of researchers on six continents, its customers include the world&rsquo;s top pharmaceutical, biotech and clinical and academic research organizations. Golden Helix products and services have been cited in over <a href="http://www.goldenhelix.com/SNP_Variation/published_articles.html">1000 peer-reviewed publications</a>. While there, I raised $1.6M in strategic investment capital and was the PI for over $1 million in SBIR research and development funding.&nbsp;I set organizational vision and strategic direction, raised investment capital, authored funded grants, and lead change management efforts. I cultivated a highly capable executive team of managers and managers of managers to carry out business operations, developing and managing organizational systems, including sales &amp; marketing, software development, product management, services delivery, human resources, legal, finance, and customer service. I sustained scientific and thought leadership for the company through <a href="https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=mGUT1T4AAAAJ"> publication</a> and speaking, with widely attended <a href="http://www.goldenhelix.com/Events/webcasts.html"> webcasts</a>&nbsp;and popular <a href="http://blog.goldenhelix.com/?author=5">blog articles</a> that advocate for systemic improvement of healthcare and research. I continually engaged in organizational excellence initiatives, integrating multiple systems disciplines for strategic and operational excellence and innovation, including <a href="http://www.tocico.org"> Theory of Constraints</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_dynamics"> System Dynamics</a>, <a href="http://globalro.org/">Requisite Organization</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TRIZ"> TRIZ</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybernetics"> Cybernetics</a>, and the <a href="http://www.goldenhelix.com/Events/recordings/learning-from-our-gwas-mistakes/index.html"> Scientific Method</a>. In 2013 I hired CEO <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/scherer"> Andreas Scherer</a> to run Golden Helix, and I continue as Chairman of the Board.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n25960									CGLambert [at] unm [dot] edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

mso 10]>  <style>   /* Style Definitions */   table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin-top:0in;   mso-para-margin-right:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;   mso-para-margin-left:0in;   line-height:107%;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:11.0pt;   font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;   mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;   mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;   mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;   mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;}  </style>  <![endif]--></p>  <p class="MsoNormal">Dr. Ji-Hyun Lee is a Professor in the UNM School of Medicine, Division of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Preventive Medicine in the Department of Internal Medicine. She is also the Director of Biostatistics Shared Resource at the UNM Comprehensive Cancer Center (UNMCCC). Dr. Lee has significant expertise in the design and conduct of cancer clinical trials, including early phase clinical trials; in the design of population cohort studies, community-based randomized control trials, and behavioral interventions; and in studies focused on cancer health disparities. To enhance the Resource&rsquo;s engagement in design, conduct, and oversight of cancer clinical trials at the UNMCCC, she leads the Biostatistics Clinical Trials Group and serves on the UNMCCC Protocol Review and Monitoring Committee (PRMC). She also directs the Resource effort in education, prioritizes and provides biostatistical support to UNMCCC researchers, mentors junior faculty, and oversees biostatistical staff. Dr. Lee is a Certified Professional Statistician through the American Statistical Association (PStat&reg;). Her research area includes: Correlated data analysis, Group/cluster randomized trials; Generalized linear mixed effects models, Cancer research in epidemiology; Health outcomes and behavior research in cancer prevention, and Best statistical practices.<br />Keywords: Cancer Research, Environmental Health, Longitudinal Data Analysis, Group Randomized Trials, and Best Statistical Practices.</p>	Ms. Connie Volker <br />Administrative Assistant <br />Email: <a href="mailto:cvolker@salud.unm.edu">cvolker@salud.unm.edu</a>&#160;&#160;&#160;<br />Phone: 505-272-4180 Fax 505-272-2570	http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n12657		New Mexico	MSC07 4025, 1 University of New Mexico	Correlated data analysis, Group/cluster randomized trials, and Best statistical practices	United States of America				jihyunlee@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Jongwon	Lee	Lee, Jongwon		Associate Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n16269	<p class="P3" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt; line-height: normal; text-indent: 0in;">Dr. Lee&#8217;s program of research focuses on Asian American women&#8217;s health within the context of culture change.&#160; She is particularly interested in research on reproductive health and prevention seeking behaviors such as cervical and breast cancer screening, contraception, unintended pregnancies and abortion, end of life, and postpartum depression. She is currently conducting a study aimed to reduce disparities in cervical cancer screening and prevention among Korean and Vietnamese American women living in NM and to develop culturally appropriate community-based interventions that meet the needs of this population. Dr. Lee&#8217;s research interest has also focused on the development and psychometric property evaluations of instruments, and theory testing, using various statistical software programs (e.g., AMOS, Mplus, LISREL, and SPSS).</p>  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt; line-height: normal;">&#160;</p>  Dr. Lee conducts both quantitative and qualitative research, and teaches research methods and advanced statistics courses to graduate nursing students.								jwlee@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Samuel	Lee	Lee, Samuel A.	87131	Professor and Regents' Lecturer		<p style="margin-top: 0.19in; margin-bottom: 0.19in; line-height: 100%;">Dr. Lee is a graduate of the Boston University School of Medicine, and completed his internship and residency at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. He completed his fellowship in Infectious Diseases at Yale University School of Medicine, and continued at Yale as a Staff Physician at VA Connecticut Healthcare System. He also obtained his Ph.D in Investigative Medicine in the Yale Graduate School. Dr. Lee then became an Assistant Professor of Medicine in the Division of Infectious Diseases, at the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, and a member of the San Antonio Center for Medical Mycology. He joined the faculty at UNM in September of 2007, and is a Professor and Section Chief, Infectious Diseases at VA Albuquerque Medical Center. He is also the Medical Director of the HIV clinic at VA Albuquerque.</p>  <p style="margin-top: 0.19in; margin-bottom: 0.19in; line-height: 100%;">Dr. Lee studies the molecular pathogenesis of invasive candidiasis and also investigates translational aspects of Candida infection, including mechanisms of echinocandin resistance and molecular epidemiology of oral candidiasis in immunosuppressed patients. A major objective of Dr. Lee&rsquo;s laboratory is to define the secretory pathways of secreted virulence proteins and determine if mutations in these pathways have an effect on virulence in vivo. He is currently studying loss-of-function mutations in several VPS (vacuole protein sorting) genes and their effects on aspartyl protease secretion, filamentation, biofilm formation, and in vivo virulence. This work is supported by a Department of Veterans Affairs MERIT award.</p>  <p style="margin-top: 0.19in; margin-bottom: 0.19in; line-height: 100%;">A second major focus of his laboratory is identification of novel secretory proteins in C. albicans and their role in virulence, using bioinformatic, genomic, and proteomic approaches. An additional goal is to identify novel markers of invasive candidiasis, as current diagnostic methods for invasive candidiasis remain sub-optimal. Dr Lee&rsquo;s lab is also involved in translational research on invasive candidiasis, including collaborative studies of echinocandin-resistance in clinical Candida isolates, and the molecular epidemiology of oral candidiasis.&nbsp;</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n728		New Mexico	Division of Infectious Diseases, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				SamALee@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Jim	Liu	Liu, Jim		Associate Dean for Research &amp; Professor		<p>Liu holds a BS in chemistry from Peking University in China (1982) and a PhD in radiation biochemistry from the University of Leeds in England (1988). He served as a research assistant professor at Dartmouth College before joining the UNM faculty in 1999.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Liu&rsquo;s research focuses broadly in two different areas of research: metal toxicity and neuroscience. In the metal research area, he investigates the molecular mechanism of arsenite and chromium-induced toxicology and carcinogenesis with particular attention to the roles of free radicals, oxidative and nitrosative modification of zinc-finger DNA repair proteins, and zinc supplement as a chemoprevention strategy for reducing arsenic toxicity and carcinogenesis. In the neuroscience area, his lab is studying and mechanism and neuroprotection of brain injury due to stroke. Liu has presented frequently at national and international conferences and given seminars at academic institutions around the world.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n3385									KLiu@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Meilian	Liu	Liu, Meilian		Assistant Professor		<strong>Academic Career</strong>  <p>Liu received her MS (2001) and PhD (2004) in biochemistry from Xiangya Medical School, Central South University, China. She completed postdoctoral training in pharmacology at the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio in 2009.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Liu&rsquo;s research aims to identify potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of obesity and its related diseases by studying the biology of white and brown adipose tissue. Her current study mainly focuses on the browning of white adipose tissue, adipokine assembly and secretion, and adipose inflammation using in vivo, ex vivo, cell culture and in vitro approaches.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n19893	Our research goal is to identify potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of obesity and its related diseases by studying the biology of white and brown adipose tissue. Our current study mainly focuses on the browning of white adipose tissue, adipokine assembly and secretion, and adipokine-mediated communication between adipose tissue and other organs&nbsp;using in vivo, ex vivo, cell culture and in vitro approaches.<br />1. Fighting&nbsp;fat&nbsp;with fat.&nbsp;There are two types of adipose tissue in our body, white adipose tissue (WAT) and brown adipose tissue (BAT). &nbsp;Very recently, it has been considered that there is a third type of adipose tissue calls brite&rdquo; or beige fat, in which uncoupling protein 1 (UCP1) expression could be stimulated by cold stress (browning) to counteract obesity as well as brown fat. We are interested in investigating how intracellular signaling pathways&nbsp;drives&nbsp;the recruitment and activation of brown and beige adipocytes&nbsp;in adipose tissue in&nbsp;response to various stimuli. <br />2.&nbsp;Cross talk between fat and other organs. WAT not only serves as an energy storage site, but also functions as an endocrine organ that regulates energy homeostasis by synthesizing and secreting molecules like adipokines. Adiponectin is an adipokine which circulates in serum in three major forms, trimer, hexamer and a high molecular weight (HMW) multimer, functions as insulin sensitizer and plays an important role in the regulation of lipid and glucose metabolism. We are highly experienced in the study of adiponectin multimerization and adiponectin-mediated cross talk between fat and other organs.									thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Jean	Lowe	Lowe, Jean		Associate Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n4026	<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">My research interests focus on the neurodevelopmental outcomes of children born preterm. Under the mentorship of Dr. Papile, I investigated outcomes of school aged children born preterm with peri-interventricular hemorrhage. Subsequent, in a multi-center grant with</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Dr. Watterberg, I began to study object permanence as a measure of early working memory in toddlers born very low birth weight (VLBW). In collaboration with the NIH Neonatal Research Network, I expanded my research using a larger cohort of children born extremely preterm, investigating the impact of early working memory and cultural diversity on developmental outcome in toddlers. I developed an ancillary study in collaboration with the NIH/NRN SUPPORT trial to examine early working memory skills in children born VLBW at 18-22 months, compared to their executive functioning skills at 6 years.</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">In collaboration with Dr. Ohls, I have expanded my research through the BRITE study, to measure the longitudinal development of children born preterm at 18 to 22 months, with subsequent evaluations at 3 to 4 years and 6 years. This was the first longitudinal study to examine the effects of Erythropoietin Stimulating Agents (ESAs) on the early executive functioning skills in children born preterm. The results of this study are now being analyzed. I will collaborate with Dr. Ohls and the BRITE research time to present and publish our findings in the coming year.</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Another area of research that continues to interest me involves early self-regulation and emotional-regulation during infancy. My work with Dr. Stephens and Dr. Bakhireva studying a cohort of infants with alcohol exposure is an ongoing study that evaluates these children at 18-22 months looking at biomarkers of alcohol exposure. Working with Dr. Handal, in the department of Public Health, we assessed a cohort of infants exposed to pesticides in Ecuador. &nbsp;We used the Still Face Paradigm to look at self-regulation skills in Ecuadorian infants, which resulted in a recent publication. In addition to this study, I published a number of research papers that looked at various aspects of parent-infant dyadic relationships and the development of emotional-regulation skills in infancy. A new study in collaboration with Dr. Carmen Herrera will allow me to expand my research in self-regulation into the Newborn Intensive Care Unit (NICU). We are planning measure heart-rate variability in parent-infant dyads as a marker of stress reactivity. Dr Herrera and I received a grant to purchase equipment that measures dyadic heart rate in neonates and their parents. We hope to find ways to reduce stress reactivity in both the parents and their critically ill infant.</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Over the past few years, I had the opportunity to facilitate a number of the medical students blocks. Together with Dr. Fuller, I mentored the class on Diversity of the Human Experience. I used problem-based learning, teaching medical students how to integrate medical information, while recognizing the unintentional biases that may occur in medicine. Dr. Fuller and I will begin teaching the Doctoring 6 class this fall. This fall I will also teach a class in clinical reasoning skills with first year medical students, an area of learning I find very important as it provides learning skills that can be assimilated in future patient care. As a mentor of students, from undergraduates to neonatal fellows, I have found this work extremely rewarding. I hope to expand my mentoring utilizing the various datasets that I have gathered collaborating on numerous different studies.</p>								JLowe@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

For the past few years I have investigated the efficacy of novel monoclonal antibodies, immunotixins and small inhibitors in the treatment of B-ALL. Specific research interests include the application of epidemiologic methods and economic evaluation to the investigation of socioeconomic disparities in access to genomic testing, medication adherence, and the design and evaluation of interventions designed to reduce inequities in cancer mortality.&nbsp;<!--EndFragment-->		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n69059				epidemiology;public health;economics;cancer care delivery research;cancer					jamcdougall@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Lana	Melendres-Groves	Melendres-Groves, Lana	87131	Assistant Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n3105		New Mexico	Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				LMelendres@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Nikolaos	Mellios	Mellios, Nikolaos				<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 150%;">Although ignored until recently for not complying with the central dogma of molecular biology, noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs) are emerging as important novel regulators of diverge cellular processes. Understanding the function of both small and large ncRNAs has led to the recognition of their ability to fine-tune the expression of numerous protein-coding genes and orchestrate the activity of complex regulatory pathways, just like a conductor in a musical performance. The capacity of ncRNAs to engage in &ldquo;molecular multitasking&rdquo; positions them to link multiple genetic risk factors for polygenic human genetic disorders into functional networks. We will utilize novel methodologies to elucidate the unexplored role of ncRNAs in both prenatal brain development and postnatal neuronal integration and utilize the attained knowledge to better understand and potentially treat neuropsychiatric disorders.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n97893									nmellios@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Miryam	Miller	Miller, Miryam		Assistant Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n27992									mirmiller@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Richard	Miller	Miller, Richard A						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n5511										thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Erin	Milligan	Milligan, Erin D				Glial cell involvement in pathological pain conditions, neuroimmune interactions in chronic inflammatory diseases of the central nervous system, spinal cord gene therapy, motor neuron degenerative diseases		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n29023	<p class="MsoNormal">Dr Milligan&#8217;s Research focuses on glial neurobiology in chronic neuropathic conditions such a pathological pain. In the clinic, existing pain treatments reduce pain by only ~25-40% in less than half of the 15 million patients suffering from chronic neuropathic pain in the US. This underscores the significance of developing new applications to identify cellular processes that not only include neurons, but also non-neurons in the central nervous system. Modern views of pain processing now include critical roles of glial cells. Following incoming pain signaling from damaged peripheral nerves, spinal cord cytokines, IL-1&#946; & TNF-&#945;, released from glia contribute to persistent pathological pain. Additionally, chemokines (chemo-tactic signaling factors that induce peripheral immune cell trafficking) interact with cytokines to further mediate pathological glial-neuronal signaling. Thus, a key focus of this lab is examining the neuroimmune mechanisms that create chronic neuropathic pain. In understanding one potential cause for when good pain turns bad, we can discover novel therapeutics to treat pain in people. One approach the lab has been focused on is to control the actions of proinflammatory cytokines by applying the anti-inflammatory cytokine, interleukin-10 (IL-10), which potently inhibits proinflammatory cytokine pain-related actions. This lab explores IL-10 gene therapy using non-viral vectors delivered to the spinal cord to control glial cell-mediated neuropathic pain.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal">Ongoing research examines several immune-related events, including chemotaxis, mitosis, and phagocytosis that may play critical roles for optimal IL-10 gene transfer in the central nervous system. Additional ongoing research explores drug-delivery devices thought to further optimize gene transfer for pain therapy. One promising approach is the use of FDA-approved synthetic co-polymers that improve IL-10 gene delivery to the spinal cord. In addition to co-polymers, we have begun to examine other drug delivery methods. Our recent endeavors include exploring entirely novel gene delivery devices that may be additionally promising for future drug development. These studies are conducted in collaboration with Dr. Brinker, Professor of Chemical and Nuclear Engineering here at UNM, who has designed nanoparticle silica cores with definable mesoporosity. Thus, we are examining these co-polymers and nanoparticle silica transgene delivery vehicles in the context of neuroimmune interactions to ultimately achieve enduring therapeutic transgene expression in the spinal cord.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal">Additional research in this lab is exploring the effects of cannabinoid compounds that are thought to selectively bind cannabinoid type 2 receptors (CB2) expressed on glial cells in the spinal cord to control chronic inflammatory spinal cord diseases including neuropathic pain. Highly selective CB2 agonists may result in anti-inflammatory activity in addition to other protective effects. We apply a variety of methods to explore the role of CB2 activation for chronic pain control that includes protein assays, and fluorescent and confocal microscopy following immunohistochemical procedures.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal">Lastly, in collaboration with the Department of Anesthesiology & Critical Care Medicine with Dr. Martin, and with the KUSAIR Imaging facility in the College of Pharmacy with Dr. Norenberg, we are refining the role that peripheral immune cells may play in mediating pathological neuronal signaling and are identifying novel therapeutic targets to control clinical pain.</p>								EMilligan@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Lucas	Miltenberger	Miltenberger, Lucas						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n45384										thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Shiraz	Mishra	Mishra, Shiraz I.				<p>I have a background&nbsp;in public health, specifically in the areas of health services and community-based chronic disease prevention/health promotion interventions.&nbsp; My main research interests and achievements have been in the characterization of individual, inter-personal, organizational/community, and societal risk factors leading to disparities in health and in access to and utilization of preventive services. I have been involved in the design, implementation, evaluation, and dissemination oftheoretically guided community-based prevention and control interventions to reduce disparities in risk factors and enhance health and well-being. For these research studies, I have incorporated mixed methods (quantitative survey methods, and qualitative focus groups and semi-structured interviews). Further, my research has provided descriptive and research-tested inferential evidence for chronic disease prevention interventions. The research has utilized the socio-ecological and social determinants frameworks for health and has been conducted in collaboration with members of diverse ethnic/racial populations (i.e., Hispanics and African Americans) and with indigenous populations (i.e., American Samoans), those residing in rural communities, and hard-to-reach populations (i.e., migrant farm workers) in the United States and internationally. More recently, I conducted two comprehensive systematic reviews (and meta-analyses) of the literature documenting the effects of exercise interventions on health-related quality of life among cancer survivors undergoing active treatment and in the post-treatment phase.&nbsp; My research has incorporated strategies to inform policy makers and stakeholders about the public health basis for policies that promote chronic disease prevention and the creation of social environments that promote social norms for health promoting behaviors. I am Professor in the Departments of Pediatrics and Family and Community Medicine. I am co-Leader of the Community Engagement and&nbsp;Research Component of the UNM Clinical and Translational Science Center (CTSC). I am also the Director of the Masters of Science in Clinical Research degree program and am the Course Director for the &ldquo;Research Design&rdquo; course.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2604	Dr. Shiraz Mishra&rsquo;s research interests are in public and international health, specifically in the area of health services. The research is based on the socio-ecological and community-oriented primary care perspectives, which provide multidisciplinary and multifactorial frameworks for prevention and socio-medical research. Dr. Mishra&rsquo;s main research achievements have been in characterizing individual, inter-personal, organizational/community, and societal risk factors leading to disparities in health and in access to and utilization of health care for chronic diseases, and the transformative translation of evidence-based knowledge through scientifically rigorous and theoretically guided community-based interventions to reduce disparities in chronic diseases and enhance health and well-being.<br /><br />Dr. Mishra&rsquo;s research has deepened our understanding of the importance of examining and addressing health and health care disparities within a multi-factorial (biology, health behavior, environment, culture, and social policies) perspective, the importance of equitable community partnerships based on mutual respect and trust both for enhancing community participation in research and for the institutionalization of evidence-based knowledge in social programs and policies, and the need for disaggregating larger geopolitical compositions of groups for the fundamental understanding of health and health disparities. He has been awarded, as Principal Investigator or Co-Investigator, over $31 million in extramural support.			control;disease prevention;Community;health disparities;Chronic illness;prevention;intervention					SMishra@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Carolyn	Montoya	Montoya, Carolyn		Professor		<p>Dr. Carolyn Jaramillo Montoya, Professor, is the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs of the UNM College of Nursing. Dr. Montoya received her bachelor's degree from the College of Nursing, University of New Mexico;&nbsp; master's degree from Yale University; and PhD from the University of New Mexico as a fellow of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Nursing and Health Policy Collaborative. <br /><br />Dr. Montoya served as President of the New Mexico Nurse Practitioner Council where she worked to achieve successful passage of legislation resulting in full prescriptive authority and independent practice for NPs in New Mexico. She has also served as President of the American College of Nurse Practitioners advocating for full scope practice for all states and President of the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners where she advocated for improving the health of children and families.&nbsp; &nbsp;<br /><br />In 2014 she was selected as a Fellow of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners and received the Western Institute of Nursing Carol A. Lindeman Award for a New Researcher for her study, "Children's Self-Perceptions of Weight in a Rural Hispanic Community".&nbsp; Dr. Montoya was inducted as a fellow of the American Academy of Nurses in October, 2016. She continues to be involved in child health care policy and policy issues related to scope of practice for advanced practice nursing and is currently serving as a member on the U.S. Health and Human Services Rural Health Advisory Committee. She received a 2-year Health and Human Services, Advanced Nursing Education Workforce grant in July of 2017 in order to develop academic-practice partnerships to prepare primary care advanced practice registered nurses to practice in rural and underserved settings.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n18659									cjmontoya@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Leslie	Morrison	Morrison, Leslie		Doctor		Our cerebrovascular research project focuses on the brain vascular malformations caused by a genetic mutation in the CCM1 gene, known as the common Hispanic mutation. We have a large patient population in New Mexico, and have established a large database with clinical, imaging, and genetic information as we search for causes of disease variability. We have a clinical trial studying simvastatin as a way to reduce permeability of CCM lesions as measured by DCE-MRI.<br /><br />Our pediatric and adult neuromuscular projects include the For-DMD international study of corticosteroid treatment in Duchenne Muscular Dystophy, and our ongoing project in Myotonic Dystrophy 1 looking at brain function.<br /><br /><br />		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n4911				cerebral cavernous malformations;myotonic dystrophy					LMorrison@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

She earned her Baccalaureate of Science in Nursing at California State University, Chico and her Master of Science in Nursing, Adult Health and Education tracks, at the University of Arizona. Nancy&rsquo;s clinical background is in adult acute and critical care. She has been certified in critical care for more than 20 years. Since Nancy&rsquo;s employment at the College in 1994, she has taught many different undergraduate courses, predominantly adult acute and critical care, internships, and pharmacology. Nancy has served extensively on the Undergraduate Committee of the College and is closely involved in curricular planning and evaluation. Albuquerque	Cristina	Murray-Krezan	Murray-Krezan, Cristina	87131	Research Assistant Professor, Biostatistician		I am a biostatistical collaborator and researcher with a broad range of expertise in statistical methods. I have a particular interest in patient-centered outcomes research, infectious diseases, health disparities, and clinical trials design. My biostatistical research area focuses on developing methods for identifying informative censoring in longitudinal studies without need to collect data from subjects after dropping out. I work with clinical and scientific faculty, fellows, residents, and post-docs on externally funded grants, internal clinical trials, and clinical studies. My collaborations with clinical researchers in the Health Sciences Center are fostered by my Division of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Preventive Medicine, as well as through the Clinical and Translational Science Center and the Cancer Center. I have served on the New Mexico Cancer Care Alliance's Protocol Review &amp; Monitoring Committee where I reviewed pharmaceutical and institutional clinical trial protocols. I also am the course director and instructor for "Biostatistics for Clinical and Translational Science" in the Master of Science in Clinical Research program. I am currently funded by PCORI, NIH, CDC, and HHS.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7474	My biostatistical research focuses on developing methods to identify informative censoring in longitudinal studies that do not require post drop-out data on subjects. 	Pavan	Muttil	Muttil, Pavan		Assistant Professor		<p>Muttil was educated in India, receiving his bachelor&rsquo;s in pharmacy in 1999 from the Dr. K.N. Modi Institute of Pharmaceutical and Educational Research in 1999, his master&rsquo;s in pharmacy from the Birla Institute of Technology &amp; Science, Pilani, in 2001 and his PhD in pharmaceutics from the Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow, in 2006. He did post-doctoral research in aerosol drug and vaccine delivery at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, before coming to UNM in 2010.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Muttil&rsquo;s expertise is in developing novel delivery systems (micro-and nanotechnology) for vaccines and drugs against infectious diseases and cancers. His laboratory focuses on the formulation and testing of dry powder vaccines and drugs in animal models, as a needle-free delivery strategy. Some of the projects being pursued in his laboratory include pulmonary drug delivery for lung cancer, pulmonary immunization against tuberculosis, needle-free vaccination strategies against bioterrorism agents and formulating immunotherapeutic agents against cancers and infectious diseases.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n639979258									pmuttil@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Orrin	Myers	Myers, Orrin	87131	Associate Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n5037	Dr. Myers came to UNM in 2000 and has been a biostatistician in the Division since 2005. He was promoted to Associate Research Professor in 2011. His main collaborations are with researchers in Nephrology, the NM HPV Pap Registry (NMHPVPR), the Clinical and Translational Science Center and with those interested in how environmental and genetic factors are associated with morbidity and mortality. Working with a nationwide, non-profit hemodialysis provider he studies treatment and patient characteristics that may influence risk of hospitalizations and mortality. The NMHPVPR is a population-based cervical screening registry using electronic medical records of screening, diagnosis, and treatment delivered in the State.&nbsp; He is currently studying how cervical screening intervals change in response to practice recommendations. He also works on two studies of air quality, pro-inflammatory cytokines, and child health that are being conducted in El&nbsp; Paso, TX, and in Quito, Ecuador.&nbsp; The El Paso study also includes genetic factors.&nbsp; Another environmental study underway will study relationships between melanoma, arsenic, and UV in NM. She has taught at Fones School of Dental Hygiene, University of Bridgeport (Connecticut) and Old Dominion University. She has been with UNM for more than 20 years.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Nathe&rsquo;s books, Dental Public Health and Research (3rd edition), and Primary Preventive Dentistry (8th edition), are used throughout the world to educate hygienists on the science and practice of dental public health and primary dental care. 	James	Nawarskas	Nawarskas, James		Associate Professor		<p>Nawarskas received a BS in pharmacy from the University of Toledo in 1993 and a PharmD from the State University of New York at Buffalo in 1995. He completed a fellowship in cardiovascular pharmacotherapy at the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy &amp; Science in 1997 and has been at UNM ever since.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Nawarskas maintains an active scholarship program in cardiovascular pharmacotherapy with an emphasis on platelet-active drugs and cardiovascular risk reduction. He is also interested in the scholarship of teaching.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n4867									JNawarskas@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Edwin	Nemoto	Nemoto, Edwin		Professor		<p>Nemoto received his BS in zoology from The George Washington University and his doctorate in physiology, biochemistry and radiation physics from Rutgers University. He has held fellowships and faculty appointments at the University of California and University of Pittsburgh. Nemoto is a highly published researcher with years of research and grant awards attributed to him. He oversees and assists the Department&rsquo;s research and enhances the education of the program&rsquo;s resident physicians.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <ul>  <li>Stroke (defining the penumbra, pathogenesis and therapy)</li>  <li>Traumatic brain injury and cerebrovascular accidents (predicting outcome, pathogenesis and therapy)</li>  <li>Brain cross-frequency coupling &#8203;(functional connectivity, brain injury, psychological states and spreading depression)</li>  <li>Mechanisms of membrane lipid modulation (of membrane enzymes and membrane receptors)</li>  </ul>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1440									ENemoto@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Scott	Ness	Ness, Scott		Professor, Cancer Genomics		<p>As a Professor of Cancer Genomics and Director of the genomics and bioinformatics shared resource, Dr. Ness focuses on translational genetics and molecular medicine.&nbsp;The Ness laboratory uses innovative approaches to study topics at the interface between cancer biology, molecular biology, stem cells, differentiation,&nbsp;transcription, epigenetics and genomics. The research in the Ness laboratory focuses on the activities and regulation of Myb transcription factors.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n6239	<p>The Ness laboratory uses innovative approaches to study important topics at the interface between cancer biology, molecular biology, stem cells, differentiation, transcription, epigenetics and genomics. Many of the research topics in our laboratory revolve around the regulation of the transcription factor c-Myb, which regulates the expression of lineage-specific genes in differentiating hematopoietic cells. The c-Myb protein regulates different genes in different hematopoietic cell types, and it regulates different genes in different parts of the cell cycle, so it must respond to different upstream signals in order to induce the expression of lineage-specific genes in different situations. We are studying the post-translational modifications and protein-protein interactions that control the activity of c-Myb in order to understand the molecular basis of differentiation and the control of cell fate.<br /><br />The c-Myb protein is the normal cellular counterpart to v-Myb, a transforming protein expressed by two avian leukemia viruses that transforms immature hematopoietic cells and induces leukemias in chickens and mice. The v-Myb protein is a mutated and activated version of c-Myb. Thus, the mutations in v-Myb appear to have unmasked the latent oncogenic potential in the c-Myb protein, using the ability of c-Myb to control differentiation and proliferation to transform cells and induce leukemia. The expression levels and activities of c-Myb are modified in numerous types of human tumors including leukemias, lymphomas, colon tumors, breast tumors and a special class of salivary gland tumors called adenoid cystic carcinomas. We study how the changes in c-Myb affect its activities and lead to tumorigenesis.<br /><br />Our laboratory uses a wide variety of different methods and techniques including molecular biology, cell biology, genetics and biochemistry. We have developed specialized adenovirus and lentivirus vectors for expressing wild type and mutant alleles of c-Myb in many different human cells, including human hematopoietic stem cells. We use microarrays, genomics and next-gen sequencing approaches to study the activities of Myb proteins in human cells, and assays of differentiation, proliferation and apoptosis to assess the biological effects.<br /><br />The Ness laboratory has been continuously supported by grants from NIH, ACS and other foundations for over 20 years and is currently supported by two grants from the National Cancer Institute and one from the Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma Research Foundation. Dr. Ness is Associate Director of the UNM Cancer Center (in charge of all shared resources) and is Director of the Keck-UNM Genomics and Bioinformatics Shared Resource.</p>  <p>Some of the projects we are currently working on include:</p>  <p>&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Regulation of c-Myb during the cell cycle (supported by an NCI R01 grant)<br />&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Characterizing the activities of c-Myb in solid tumors (supported by a grant from the Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma Research Foundation, ACCRF)<br />&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Using next-gen sequencing to analyze and determine the importance of alternative RNA splicing in&nbsp; pediatric leukemia (supported by a Provocative Questions R01 from NCI)</p>			Hematopoiesis;Oncogenes;Cancer Biology;stem cells;Differentiation;Gene Regulation					SNess@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Aaron	Neumann	Neumann, Aaron						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n4133	<ul>  <li>Cell biology and signal transduction of fungal pathogen sensing via C-type lectins in dendritic cells and macrophages</li>  <li>Innate immune fungal recognition in the context of medically-relevant biofilm microbial communities formed by Candida genus human fungal pathogens</li>  <li>Influence of fungal call wall moieties on the success or failure of anti-fungal immunity</li>  <li>Quantitative live cell optical microscopy techniques to investigate host-microbe interactions between primary human innate immune cells and fungal pathogens</li>  </ul>								AKNeumann@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
