	A Mary	Vilay	Vilay, Mary		Assistant Professor		<p>Vilay was educated in Canada, receiving a BS in pharmacy from the University of Alberta in 2000 and a PharmD from the University of Toronto in 2007.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Vilay studies drug pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics in patients with chronic kidney disease and acute kidney injury in order to optimize drug therapies and the delivery of kidney dialysis. Clinical studies she has been involved in have resulted in dosing recommendations for ertapenem and daptomycin in critically ill patients undergoing continuous hemodialysis.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1504	Mary Vilay, PharmD, accepts AACP $10,000 New Investigator Award Grant for dialysis research source: http://hsc.unm.edu/pharmacy/News/			Pharmacy practice and administrative sciences					MVilay@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Dennis	Villareal	Villareal, Dennis	87131	Professor		I am a physician-scientist with board certification in geriatrics and endocrinology. The overall goal of my research program is to define strategies to improve the physical capacity of obese older adults and prevent their loss of independence. I have considerable experience in lifestyle therapy to reverse frailty in obese older adults. As summarized in the American Society of Nutrition and Obesity Society position statement, in which I was the lead author, obesity in older adults is a major public health problem because it exacerbates the agerelated decline in physical function and causes frailty. I was the first to report that frailty is, in fact, common in obese community-living older men and women. Although weight loss may improve physical function, it may also induce loss of muscle and bone mass. Accordingly, I have been designing lifestyle interventions (weight loss + various exercises) to maximally improve physical function while preserving muscle and bone mass in obese older adults. I have completed a number of randomized controlled trials providing preliminary evidence that lifestyle therapy can reverse frailty in obese older adults. My work has been recognized with the best paper award on &ldquo;Research on Geriatric Syndromes&rdquo; from the American Geriatrics Society, and I am a frequent invited speaker on the clinical approach to obese older adults. Based on previous work, the current standard exercise prescription (combined aerobic/resistance training) for older adults does not appear to prevent weightloss induced muscle and bone mass (but only attenuate it) likely as a result of interference between the specific adaptations to different exercises.<br /><br />Accordingly, the current study, which directly compares (head-head comparison) the potential of resistance, aerobic, and combined resistance/exercise to improve physical function and reverse frailty in obese older adults is a progression of my previous work. The study is highly interdisciplinary, clinical, and translational with an immediate/direct application to the clinical care of the growing number of obese older adults characterized by sarcopenic obesity and frailty. Overall, my track record and expertise in the field of lifestyle therapy of older adults places me in an exceptional position to lead this important clinical investigation.<br />		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n882		New Mexico	Division of Geriatrics and Palliative Medicine, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				DVillareal@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Reina	Villareal	Villareal, Reina	87131	Associate Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7716		New Mexico	Division of Endocrinology and Metabolism, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				RVillareal@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Mary	Walker	Walker, Mary K.		Professor of Pharmacology and Toxicology<br />UNM Regents' Professor		<p>Walker was educated at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. She received a BS in agricultural journalism (1984) and a BS in wildlife ecology (1984) and a PhD in environmental toxicology (1991).</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Walker is an expert in vascular physiology and toxicology. Her laboratory actively uses preclinical genetically modified mouse models to investigate mechanisms by which cigarette smoke induces vascular dysfunction and hypertension and conducts clinical translational studies in human cigarette smokers to identify potential new biomarkers of cardiovascular disease risk and novel therapeutic targets to prevent and treat cigarette smoke-induced vascular disease.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n5932									MWalker@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Nina	Wallerstein	Wallerstein, Nina		Professor		<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings> <o:AllowPNG /> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings> </xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading" /> </w:LatentStyles> </xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 10]>  <style>   /* Style Definitions */   table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin-top:0in;   mso-para-margin-right:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;   mso-para-margin-left:0in;   line-height:115%;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:11.0pt;   font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";   mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;   mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;   mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;   mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;}  </style>  <![endif]-->Nina Wallerstein, Dr. P.H., is professor of Public Health in the College of Population Health, and was the founding director of the Master in Public Health Program at the University of New Mexico until 2007. She currently is the director of the Center for Participatory Research.&nbsp; She received her Dr. P.H. at the School of Public Health, University of California, Berkeley. For over 30 years, she has been involved in empowerment/popular education, and participatory research with youth, women, tribes, and community building efforts. She is the co-editor of Community Based Participatory Research for Health, 2nd edition, 2008 (with Meredith Minkler); coauthor of Problem-Posing at Work: Popular Educator's Guide; and author of several health and adult education books and over 100 articles and book chapters on participatory intervention research, adolescent health promotion, alcohol and addictions prevention research, empowerment theory, and popular health education. Her current research interests focus on community capacity and health development in tribal communities, culturally appropriate translational intervention research, participatory evaluation, and community-based participatory research processes and outcomes.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n3442	<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings> <o:AllowPNG /> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings> </xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument> <w:View>Normal</w:View> <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom> <w:TrackMoves /> <w:TrackFormatting /> <w:PunctuationKerning /> <w:ValidateAgainstSchemas /> <w:SaveIfXMLInvalid>false</w:SaveIfXMLInvalid> <w:IgnoreMixedContent>false</w:IgnoreMixedContent> <w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText>false</w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText> Locked="false" Priority="19" SemiHidden="false"    UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Emphasis" /> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="21" SemiHidden="false" <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"    UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference" /> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"    UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title" /> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography" /> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading" /> </w:LatentStyles> </xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 10]>  <style>   /* Style Definitions */   table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin-top:0in;   mso-para-margin-right:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;   mso-para-margin-left:0in;   line-height:115%;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:11.0pt;   font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";   mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;   mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;   mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;   mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;}  </style>  <![endif]-->  <p class="MsoNormal">I bring more than 30 years of experience with empowerment-based interventions and CBPR research in adolescent and women&rsquo;s health, alcohol and substance abuse prevention, W.H.O. healthy communities in the U.S. and Latin America, tribal community capacity development, and culturally-centered intervention development with tribes. I have co-edited the first major textbook on CBPR, Community Based Research for Health: From Process to Outcomes, 2nd edition, San Francisco, Jossey-Bass; a textbook on Freirian popular education, Problem-Posing at Work: A Popular Educators Guide, 2004; and written on methods, ethics, and outcomes of CBPR, as well as a major literature review of empowerment studies for the WHO health evidence network I have also co-edited a text on cultural approaches to Substance Abuse prevention and treatment: Wallerstein, N., Miller, W. R., &amp; Duran, B. (Eds.). Interventions for Alcohol Problems in Minority and Rural Populations: Taylor &amp; Francis, Inc., 2008.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal">As an NIAAA and NARCH (NIDA-funded) researcher, I have confronted challenges of CBPR implementation research; developed empowerment and capacity items for intervention research for children, adolescents, women, and parents (most recently with two tribal family prevention translational research projects); and have co-developed with my research team new qualitative and quantitative assessments of tribal capacities, incorporating cultural appropriateness of response codes, such as a yes/no response for instruments in the Navajo language and tribally-specific items for leadership, participation, language and cultural capacities unique to tribes. I have been working in teenage empowerment interventions since my work with the Adolescent Social Action Project (ASAP), (NIAAA, R01 AA08943-01A3), where we developed empowerment Freire-based dialogical curriculum for and with minority high risk adolescents. Our logic model represented a similar trajectory to impact self-efficacies, and self-and other-protective cognitive-behaviors and reduce onset of drug and alcohol risky behaviors, through experiential, dialogical, and community action projects. There were program effects on several cognitive variables, in particular, protection of family response efficacy, protection of friend's response efficacy, empathy, and perceived control. Multivariate analysis of empathy and social relationships, and the variable, social bonding was significant at the six month follow-up. Intervention males at six months had significant advantage over the control group in five variables: severity of risk, protection of friend's response efficacy, protection of friends self-efficacy, perceived control and social bonding. Program effects on drinking behavior was significant at the six month follow up for students from the schools designated as good implementation sites with staff who were consistently committed to the ASAP program. Youth measurement items of self and collective efficacy from ASAP were incorporated into my later work in YouthLink (Springett and Wallerstein, 2008) and are incorporated into the RezRIDER pre and post test.</p>								NWallerstein@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Angela	Wandinger-Ness	Wandinger-Ness, Angela	87131	Professor		<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:DocumentProperties> <o:Template>Normal.dotm</o:Template> <o:Revision>0</o:Revision> <o:TotalTime>0</o:TotalTime> <o:Pages>1</o:Pages> <o:Words>37</o:Words> <o:Characters>213</o:Characters> <o:Company>UNM</o:Company> <o:Lines>1</o:Lines> <o:Paragraphs>1</o:Paragraphs> <o:CharactersWithSpaces>261</o:CharactersWithSpaces> <o:Version>12.257</o:Version> </o:DocumentProperties> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings> <o:AllowPNG /> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings> </xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument> <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom> <w:TrackMoves>false</w:TrackMoves> <w:TrackFormatting /> <w:PunctuationKerning /> <w:DrawingGridHorizontalSpacing>18 pt</w:DrawingGridHorizontalSpacing> <w:DrawingGridVerticalSpacing>18 pt</w:DrawingGridVerticalSpacing> <w:DisplayHorizontalDrawingGridEvery>0</w:DisplayHorizontalDrawingGridEvery> <w:DisplayVerticalDrawingGridEvery>0</w:DisplayVerticalDrawingGridEvery> <w:ValidateAgainstSchemas /> <w:SaveIfXMLInvalid>false</w:SaveIfXMLInvalid> <w:IgnoreMixedContent>false</w:IgnoreMixedContent> <w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText>false</w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText> <w:Compatibility> <w:BreakWrappedTables /> <w:DontGrowAutofit /> <w:DontAutofitConstrainedTables /> <w:DontVertAlignInTxbx /> </w:Compatibility> </w:WordDocument> </xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:LatentStyles DefLockedState="false" LatentStyleCount="276"> </w:LatentStyles> </xml><![endif]--> <!--  /* Font Definitions */ @font-face  {font-family:Arial;  mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;  mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;  mso-style-noshow:yes;  mso-style-parent:"";  mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;  mso-para-margin-top:0in;  mso-para-margin-right:0in;  mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt;  mso-para-margin-left:0in;  line-height:115%;  mso-pagination:widow-orphan;  font-size:12.0pt;  font-family:"Times New Roman";  mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;  mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;  mso-fareast-font-family:"&#65325;&#65331;  panose-1:2 11 6 4 2 2 2 2 2 4;  mso-font-charset:0;  mso-generic-font-family:auto;  mso-font-pitch:variable;  mso-font-signature:-536859905 -1073711037 9 0 511 0;} @font-face  {font-family:Arial;  panose-1:2 11 6 4 2 2 2 2 2 4;  mso-style-qformat:yes;  mso-style-parent:"";  margin-top:0in;  margin-right:0in;  margin-bottom:10.0pt;  margin-left:0in;  line-height:115%;  mso-pagination:widow-orphan;  font-size:11.0pt;  font-family:Calibri;  mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;  mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;  mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;  mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;  mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;  mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;  mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";  mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;} .MsoChpDefault  {mso-style-type:export-only;  mso-default-props:yes;  font-size:11.0pt;  mso-ansi-font-size:11.0pt;  mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;  font-family:Calibri;  mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;  mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;  mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;  mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;  mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;  mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;  mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";  mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;} .MsoPapDefault  {mso-style-type:export-only;  margin-bottom:10.0pt;  line-height:115%;} @page WordSection1  {size:8.5in 11.0in;  margin:1.0in 1.25in 1.0in 1.25in;  mso-header-margin:.5in;  mso-footer-margin:.5in;  mso-paper-source:0;} div.WordSection1  {page:WordSection1;} -->  <p>Rab and Rho GTPases function as molecular switches in the cellular circuitry governing cell behaviors. Upstream signaling cascades feed in to turn on specific GTPases, which in turn couple to downstream effectors that control cell growth, differentiation, adhesion and motility.&nbsp; Mutation of Rab GTPases or associated regulatory proteins underlies numerous human genetic diseases. Cancer, neurodegeneration and diabetes represent examples of acquired human diseases resulting from the up- or downregulation or aberrant function of Rab and Rho GTPases.</p>  <p>The Wandinger-Ness laboratory utilizes sophisticated microscopic imaging technologies, flow cytometry, protein biochemistry, cell biology and genomics to address questions related to the pathogenesis and treatment of peripheral neuropathies, ovarian cancer and kidney disease.&nbsp; New technologies and discoveries have been translated to 6 patents and invention disclosures. &nbsp;The group is highly collaborative and interdisciplinary with research partners in Canada, Germany, the United Kingdom, as well as in the College of Pharmacy, the School of Medicine, and the School of Engineering at the University of New Mexico (UNM).</p>	New Mexico	2325 Camino de Salud CRF225, Dept Pathology MSC08 4640	Cell Biology;Ovarian cancer;Therapeutic targeting of Ras related GTPases;Ciliary trafficking and signaling;Endocytosis;Membrane Trafficking;Renal stem cells and regenerative medicine;Drug discovery;Kidney disease	United States of America				AWandinger@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Heather	Webb	Webb, Heather		Assistant Professor and Medical, SRMC Emergency Department				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n2964									HWebb@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Jason	Weick	Weick, Jason P				Work in the Weick lab centers on understanding multiple aspects of the development of functional neural circuits, from how individual neurons acquire functional properties to how groups of neurons generate patterns of information. Using neurons differentiated from pluripotent stem cells we study development both under normal conditions and in the context of developmental disorders. First, we have recently identified an uncharacterized protein that is strongly upregulated as neuroepithelial cells differentiate to post-mitotic neurons, but is subsequently downregulated in adults. It is part of a family of proteins, the other members of which are known to associate with, and aid in the shuttling of receptors within post-synpatic compartments. We hypothesize that this protein plays a central role in delivering molecular components involved with neurotransmission to the plasma membrane during a critical period of development. Secondly, new projects are focusing on aberrant development of neural circuits caused by genetic or environmental abnormalities that result in intellectual disabilities. For instance, we have identified an abnormal pattern of activity in in vitro cultures of neurons that carry trisomy 21, the underlying cause of Down Syndrome. Current investigations seek to understand the molecular cause of this abnormality. Lastly, we are investigating the effects of ethanol on developing neurons during early stages of synapse formation.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n33430									JPWeick@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

Albuquerque	Bridget	Wilson	Wilson, Bridget S	87131-0001	Professor		<p>The Wilson laboratory combines an interest in signal transduction and membrane organization/trafficking in the context of normal and disease cells. Funding in the laboratory comes from R01 grants awarded by NIAID and NCI, as well as an NIGMS P50 grant to support the New Mexico Spatiotemporal Modeling Center (STMC). We also acknowledge important prior funding from the Leukemia/Lymphoma Society and the American Cancer Society.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n611185918	<strong>Membrane Microdomains</strong>  <p>We use innovative microscopic approaches to follow the reorganization of plasma membrane signaling components during signaling. One important method is immunoelectron microscopy of native membrane sheets (&#8220;rip-flips&#8221;), which provides high spatial resolution. This is complemented by live cell imaging approaches for temporal resolution (in collaboration with Dr. Diane Lidke). We primarily focus on these classes of receptors:</p>  <ol>  <li>  <p>Fc receptors, particularly the high affinity IgE receptor, Fc&#949;RI of mast cells and basophils. We have described residency of receptors in &#8220;Protein Islands&#8221; as well as confinement in cytoskeletal corrals. The effects of spatial organization upon FceRI signaling and internalization mechanisms are our primary focus.</p>  </li>  <li>  <p>ErbB family of receptors, particularly in the context of ovarian cancer (UNM clinical partner, Dr. Carolyn Muller). This work is aligned with the Interagency Modeling and Analysis Group initiative for multi-scale modeling. For information on this program, go to <a href="http://www.nibib.nih.gov/Research/MultiScaleModeling/IMAG">http://www.nibib.nih.gov/Research/MultiScaleModeling/IMAG</a>.</p>  </li>  <li>  <p>Receptors and accessory molecules involved in growth and survival of pre-B acute lymphoblastic leukemia (UNM clinical partner, Dr. Stuart Winter). A new initiative focuses on the mechanisms and efficacy of therapeutic monoclonal antibodies, including Fc&#947;R-mediated killing of antibody-bound leukemia target cells by macrophages and NK cells.</p>  </li>  </ol><strong>Organization and Dynamics of Calcium Stores</strong>  <p>We use a combination of high resolution microscopy and mathematical modeling to study calcium mobilization in the context of cell geometry. Current efforts are concentrated on the dynamics and spatial aspects of Orai1-STIM1 coupling in antigen-stimated mast cells.</p>	New Mexico	1 University of New Mexico, MSC08 4640		United States of America				BWilson@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Bronwyn	Wilson	Wilson, Bronwyn	87131	Senior Associate Dean for Academic Affairs				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1578		New Mexico	Division of General Internal Medicine, DoIM MSC10 5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				BEWilson@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Colin	Wilson	Wilson, Colin						http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n108805									cmwilson@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Michael	Wilson	Wilson, Michael C		Faculty		Ca<sup>++</sup> regulated exocytotic release of neurotransmitters provides for chemical signaling between neurons and neuroendocrine cells and their postsynaptic target cells. Our laboratory is interested in the regulation of neurotransmitter release, and its impact on nervous system development and function, and how it contributes to behavior, learning and memory. Our studies are focused on genetic manipulations of the gene encoding SNAP-25, which together with integral membrane proteins syntaxin and synaptobrevin/VAMP constitute the neural SNARE core machinery required for Ca<sup>++</sup>-triggered neuroexocytotic release of neurotransmitters. To better understand mechanisms that underlie synaptic transmission, we have emphasized a molecular genetic approach integrated with developmental, physiological and behavioral analyses. Most recently, this includes developing homologous recombination knock-out and knock-in mutations of the Snap25 gene in the mouse. Our studies have revealed the role of neural SNARE complexes in promoting regulated action potential-dependent and &ndash;independent modes of neurotransmitter release (&ldquo;singing&rdquo; and &ldquo;humming&rdquo; by neurons) and its impact on nervous system development, synapse formation and maturation. Current investigations are continuing to evaluate the mechanisms responsible for change in the exocytotic machinery, Ca<sup>++</sup>-dependency and efficacy of synaptic communication, and how they affect neural plasticity required for learning and memory in these mutant mice. Based on our early investigations of the SNAP-25 deficient mutant mouse Coloboma and more recently by genetic association studies in human populations, the SNAP25 gene has been considered as a potential susceptibility locus for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), the most prevalent neuropsychiatric disorder in children. Together with Drs. <a href="http://hsc.unm.edu/som/neurosciences/fac_partridge.shtml"> Don Partridge</a> and <a href="http://hsc.unm.edu/som/neurosciences/fac_allan.shtml"> Andrea Allan</a> in the Neurosciences Department, we are evaluating the electrophysiological, pharmacological and behavioral consequences in mice that result from a deficiency of SNAP-25 expression together with prenatal nicotine exposure, a risk factor of maternal smoking during pregnancy for ADHD. By taking this multidisciplinary approach we hope to achieve a mechanistic understanding of the role of gene x environment interactions during the development of cognitive deficiencies and mental illness in humans.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1350874925									mwilson@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

	Joy	Wortham	Wortham , Joy		Assistant Professor, Department of Internal Medicine				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n57747										thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Mary	Wright	Wright, Mary		Lecturer III		<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 10pt;">Mary Wright is a Clinical Educator at the College of Nursing, Health Sciences Center, University of New Mexico. Mary earned her ADN in 1975 from the University of Albuquerque, her BSN in 1989 and then her MSN (dual focus in Community Health and Nursing Administration) from the University of New Mexico in 1993.</p>  Mary started teaching full-time at the College of Nursing in 1998. She teaches health and illness concepts and maternal-newborn nursing content in the BSN program as well as a &lsquo;Teaching in Nursing&rsquo; course in the Nursing Education concentration for the MSN program. During her time at UNM, Mary has been a leader in curriculum revision and new curriculum design and development for the CoN. She is stays involved with the Student Nurses&rsquo; Association (SNA) at UNM as a faculty advisor.		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7061									mwright@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Terry	Wu	Wu, Terry	87131	Associate&nbsp;Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n7454	Dr. Wu is currently working to develop vaccines, therapeutics, and diagnostics for human respiratory tularemia. Tularemia is caused by the gram-negative bacteria <em>Francisella tularensis</em> and the respiratory form of the disease is associated with a mortality rate approaching 30%, if not promptly diagnosed and treated. Proper diagnosis of this disease is difficult because the symptoms resemble many other respiratory infections and treatment may suffer from patient non-compliance due to the prolonged treatment regimen required to cure the disease. Moreover, it is not possible to vaccinate against this disease because no vaccine has been approved by the FDA. Given these challenges, the lab is working to develop: 1) a safe and effective tularemia vaccine that can be administered using a needle-free method; 2) a therapeutic drug formulation that would be effective as a single dose; and 3) a rapid and highly specific method to diagnose tularemia. Dr. Wu is funded by the National Institute of Allergies and Infectious Disease and Defense Threat Reduction Agency.	New Mexico	Center for Global Health, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				TWu@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4

mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin-top:0in;   mso-para-margin-right:0in; <![endif]--></p>  <p class="MsoNormal">Guangbin Xia, MD, PhD. is an associate professor in Department of Neurology and Neuroscience of University of New Mexico. Dr. Xia got his MD degree in Shanghai, China and his PhD degree in Tokyo, Japan. He had further scientific training as a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Southern California. Subsequently, he had his Medicine Internship training in the University of Virginia and Neurology Residency training in University of Texas Medical Branch and University of Florida. He completed his fellowship training in neuromuscular medicine in University of Florida. He was the former trainee of Clinical Research Consortium for Spinocerebellar Ataxias (CRC-SCA)/NIH. He has recently moved to University of New Mexico. His lab locates in the Facility for Advanced Cell Engineering (FACE) in the Health Science Center. His research focus on &nbsp;therapeutic development using induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cell and therapeutic genome editing technologies for neurodegenerative disorders, including &nbsp;myotonic dystrophy, spinocerebellar ataxia, and motor neuron diseases.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n85258	<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>   <w:WordDocument>    <w:View>Normal</w:View> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="52"     Name="List Table 7 Colorful Accent 6"/>   </w:LatentStyles>  </xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 10]>  <style>   /* Style Definitions */   table.MsoNormalTable   {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";   mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;   mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;   mso-style-noshow:yes;   mso-style-priority:99;   mso-style-parent:"";   mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;   mso-para-margin:0in;   mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;   mso-pagination:widow-orphan;   font-size:10.0pt;   font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;   mso-fareast-language:EN-US;}  </style>  <![endif]-->  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 3.0pt;"><strong>1. Myotonic Dystrophy:</strong> We have established disease-specific DM1 cell iPS cell lines. These cells are being distributed for mechanistic studies, drug screening, cell replacement and genome editing studies. We have successfully modified DM1 iPS cells. Genome-modified human DM1 iPS cells maintain their pluripotency. DM1 iPS cells as well as the linearly differentiated NSCs, neurons, astrocytes, and cardiomyocytes all lost nuclear RNA foci and demonstrated reversal of aberrant splicing. These cells will pave the way for cell transplantation for advanced DM1 disease. However, in vivo genome therapy at the early stage may prevent the onset and progression of the disease and may also provide treatment of congenital myotonic dystrophy. We are using the same strategy to develop in vivo genome therapy for DM1. With the advancement of gene editing tools, especially RNA guided endonuclease, including CRISPR/Cas9, we hypothesize that in vivo genome modification will be a safe and effective treatment for DM1.</p>  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 3.0pt;"><strong>2. Spinocerebellar Ataxias (SCA):</strong> We have established disease-specific iPS cells for SCA2, SCA 3 and SCA 10.&nbsp; These created ideal cellular models. These cells are being distributed nationally and internationally for the advancement of the studies. Currently, we are using SCA disease-specific iPS cells for mechanistic studies, drug screening, cell replacement and genome editing studies. Dr. Xia has conducted an investigator-initiated clinical trial as PI evaluating the effect of Dalfampridine on SCAs. Dr. Xia is a member of&nbsp; joined Clinical Research Consortium for Spinocerebellar Ataxias (CRC-SCA)/NIH and is&nbsp; participating collaborative studies. </p>	New Mexico	Dept. of Neurology, MSC 10-5620, 1 University of New Mexico	myotonic dystrophy;therapeutic development;induced pluripotent stem cells;Nucleotide repeat expansion;genome editing;Motor neuron disease;Spinocerebellar ataxia;Muscular dystrophy	United States of America			Dr.	guxia@saluld.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Zhi	Xu	Xu, Zhi	87131	Visiting Associate Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n12523		New Mexico	Division of Nephrology, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				ZXu@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Xiang	Xue	Xue, Xiang		Assistant Profeesor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n18240				Infammation;Colorectal Cancer;Iron Metabolism					xxue@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Janice	Yager	Yager, Janice	87131	Professor		<p>Dr. Janice W. Yager has extensive experience designing and conducting environmental and occupational health research that includes laboratory investigation as well as population studies.&nbsp; Her research has focused on development and translation of biological monitoring (biomarker) methods that reflect exposure and early&nbsp;biological effects. She has received a number of awards for scientific excellence in research including an NIH Fogarty International Fellowship.&nbsp; She has served&nbsp;on executive committees of a number of professional societies and&nbsp;as an invited member of state, federal, and international environmental health scientific advisory committees including the National Academy of Sciences, US Environmental Protection Agency, the World Health Organization and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.&nbsp; She is author or co-author of more than&nbsp;65 publications in refereed journals, monographs and book chapters.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n476	Dr. Yager is engaged in several areas of environmental health sciences research as part-time research faculty with emphasis on gaining understanding of molecular toxicology mode of action of environmental agents using genomic microarray technology and other advanced techniques.&nbsp; An overarching goal is to contribute to improvement of scientifically based health risk assessments aimed at prevention of adverse health outcomes associated with environmental and occupational exposures.&nbsp; One currently ongoing study&nbsp; is assessment of the interaction of UV and arsenic exposure in relation to potential interference in DNA repair in an in vitro melanocyte model and, in parallel, an observational study of cutaneous malignant melanoma cases compared with a reference population.&nbsp; Dr. Yager's focus on understanding specific toxicological and exposure mechanisms and their interactions is imperative to accurately assessing population health risk due to environmental exposure via multiple routes.&nbsp; She has long term interest and experience in development of human biomarkers relevant to assessment of the biological impact of environmental and occupational exposures toward utilization of findings for disease prevention.	New Mexico	Division of Epidemiology, Biostatistics, and Preventive Medicine, DoIM MSC10-5550, 1 University of New Mexico		United States of America				JWYager@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
	Xuexian	Yang	Yang, Xuexian		Assistant Professor				http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1559				T Helper Cell;allergies;autoimmune disease;neuroinflammation;Cytokine signaling;inflammatory disease;Transcriptional control					XYang@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
Albuquerque	Yi	Yang	Yang, Yi	87131	Research Professor		<p style="margin: 0in 0in 8pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 150%;">Dr. Yi Yang is a Research Professor of Neurology. She holds MD., M.S, and PhD in medicine and neuroscience from the Chongqing Medical University in China, and received her post-doctoral trainings at Bejing Institute of Basic Medical Sciences, The University of Hong Kong in China, and&nbsp;University of New Mexico School of Medicine. Her NIH- and AHA-funded research programs are aimed at understanding the mechanisms of brain injury and repair associated with stroke, vascular cognitive impairment, and other neurological disorders.&nbsp; Dr. Yang&rsquo;s laboratory is particularly focused on translational potential and cellular and molecular mechanisms of blood-brain barrier restoration and functional vascular remodeling following ischemic stroke as well as short- and long-term effects of neuroprotective agents. <br /><a href="http://neurology.unm.edu/research/neuroscience-research/yang-lab.html">http://neurology.unm.edu/research/neuroscience-research/yang-lab.html</a></p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n31550	<p style="margin: 0in 0in 8pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 150%;">The research of Yi Yang&rsquo;s Laboratory is focused on translational potential and understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms of brain injury and neurovascular remodeling associated with ischemic stroke and other neurological disorders. The long-term goal is to facilitate the development of more precisely targeted therapeutic approaches to reduce the progressive brain injury cascade and to improve recovery following neurological disorders.</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 8pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 150%;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Laboratory&rsquo;s earlier work has been seminal in defining the role of the matrix metalloproteinase (MMPs) in the disruption of the tight junction proteins (TJPs) in blood-brain barrier (BBB) after stroke. Studies on alternate roles of MMPs in the cell nucleus on DNA repair and neuronal apoptotic death has been pioneering in the field. Findings in the Laboratory also indicated the critical role of MMPs, particularly MMP-2 and -3, in stroke-induced angiogenesis during brain repair.&nbsp;</p>  <p style="margin: 0in 0in 8pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 150%;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Recently, The Yang Laboratory demonstrated that spontaneous angiogenic vessels in peri-infarct area have high BBB permeability due to lack of two major endothelial TJPs. These findings emphasize the current challenges to promote angiogenesis in ischemic brain as a therapeutic strategy: facilitation of functional BBB restoration and determination of appropriate points of intervention for functional vascular remodeling. Further studies based on animal model and cell cultures have demonstrated that cross-talk between cells in neurovascular unit, such as pericytes, astrocytes, and microglia, plays a critical role in BBB restoration in newly formed vessels in peri-infarct area during stroke recovery.</p>  &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The primary focus of Yang&rsquo;s current NIH-and AHA-funded projects is to characterize the cellular and molecular mechanisms through which angiogenesis functional BBB is formed in response to spontaneous and therapy-induced vascular remodeling during recovery, as well as to monitor dynamic profile of functional neurovascular remodeling during recovery from stroke utilizing interdisciplinary methods. Additional interests of the laboratory are to elucidate the role of NG2-pericyte pathway in the regulation of TJPs formation of BBB during stroke-induced vascular remodeling. Experimental approaches involved include rodent models of cerebral ischemia, neuronal and 3D BBB cultures, mouse genetic models, MRI, specific antibody-conjugated nanoparticles, biochemical and molecular studies, histological and behavioral evaluation. 	Howard	Yonas	Yonas, Howard		Distinguished Professor and Chair of the Department of Neurosurgery		<p>Yonas played a key role in establishing the UNM Department of Neurosurgery following a long career at the University of Pittsburgh. During his tenure, UNM&rsquo;s programs in clinical neurosurgery and neurosurgical research have expanded.</p>  <p>Notable achievements include the establishment of the 24-bed Neurosciences Intensive Care Unit, development of a multi-specialty neuroscience outpatient clinic and the creation of a statewide telemedicine network for evaluating and managing acute stroke. In addition, the Department&rsquo;s resident training program has received full certification from the Accreditation Council of Graduate Medical Education.</p>  <p>Yonas is the 2015 Neurosciences Award recipient and was one of two recipients of the 2014 UNM Presidential Award of Distinction.</p>  <p>Yonas obtained his medical degree from The Ohio State University. He completed an internship and residency in neurosurgery at Case Western Reserve University and also served in the U.S. Air Force as a flight surgeon. He later completed fellowships in microsurgery in Zurich and in Pittsburgh. He joined the University of Pittsburgh faculty in 1978, became a tenured professor in 1988 and was named the Peter J. Jannetta Professor of Neurosurgery in 1995. He served as the vice chair of the department and the Director of Cerebrovascular Surgery. Dr. Yonas helped create and served as the co-director of the University Of Pittsburgh Medical Center Stroke Institute.</p>  <p><strong>Research Interests</strong></p>  <p>Yonas is the principal investigator on a $15.1 million Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services Innovations Grant awarded in September 2014. The three-year Access to Critical Cerebral Emergency Support Services (ACCESS) grant puts state-of-the art telehealth technology in 30 New Mexico hospitals to provide emergent neurological and neurosurgical consultations.</p>  <p>He is also involved in developing new technologies to improve the understanding and treatment of cerebrovascular and traumatic disorders of the brain. He helped develop and implement the use of quantitative cerebral blood flow measurements using a combination of stable xenon inhalation and CT scanning.</p>		http://vivo.health.unm.edu/individual/n1216841747									hyonas@salud.unm.edu	thing;agent;person;bfo1;fac;bfo2;bfo4
